NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 Oct, the house of a murdered JKPDP ex-sarpanch was set ablaze by unknown persons in the Imamsahib area of Shopian. He was murdered by suspected militants a day before.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On October 17, armed forces (assumed police and military) staged night raids on the houses of militants in several villages in Shopian district (J&K), causing a lot of damage to houses.
On October 20, at least four vehicles and a railway track were set on fire by CPI-Maoist cadres in Dantewada district.

Arrests: On October 21st, Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, leader of the Awami Action Committee which is part of the All Parties Hurriyat Conference was put under house arrest in Srinagar ahead of his scheduled visit to the Charar-e-Sharif shrine.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKPDP: Jammu and Kashmir Peoples Democratic Party
NOTES: Property destruction: On 21 Oct, militants vandalised the house of JKPDP zonal president Muhammad Ashraf in Dadsara village of Tral while he was on a trip elsewhere.

Property destruction: On October 21st, 2-3 militants vandalised the house of Territorial Army jawan, Ishfaq Ahmad, in Zasoo Tahab (Pulwama, J&K), while he wasn't home, and scared his family by firing shots into the air.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On October 22, militants ransacked the house of a policeman at 10pm in Batagund village (Pulwama, J&K) vandalizing his property. No injuries were reported and family members fled beforehand.
Defusal: Police safely detonated an IED planted at the house of a civilian by an unidentified group in Porompat on 24 October 2017.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 2 November, members of the Bomb Disposal Squad defused a live grenade which had been found outside the DM office in Kupwara town (J&K).
On November 4, CPI-Maoist cadres set nine vehicles ablaze at the road construction site in Narengtola in Kalyansinghpur of Rayagada district.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKLF: Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front
NOTES: Arrests: On Nov 27, the chairman of Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front (JKLF), Muhammad Yasin Malik, was detained at his Maisuma residence in Srinagar to prevent him from leading protests in Srinagar.
On December 5, CPI-Maoist set ablaze several vehicles including an earthmover and two tractors, in Gumla's Basia area at the site of a canal construction project.
On Dec 7, security forces defused a grenade found in Tral area (Pulwama, J&K).

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On December 7, a group of over 100 RR soldiers burnt large quantity of villagers' stacks and dried grass at Mir Mohalla village in the Hajan area (Bandipora, J&K), depriving them of ways to feed their cattle during the winter. They also vandalized properties, smashing windows and boundary walls.
On December 8, CPI-Maoist cadres opposing road construction, set six vehicles at a road construction site ablaze, in Gumla's Ghaghra area.

Defusal: On Dec 8 night, an IED was dedected and defused on the railway track between Chhipadohar and Barwadih railway stations (Latehar district, Jharkhand). During the subsequent search operation in the area, the security forces also found another IED under a bush. Security forces suspect that Maoists planted the bomb.
Arrests: On Dec 15, hours before a proposed separatist rally by Joint Resistance Leadership (JRL), several separatist leaders and activists were detained by the police in Srinagar district.

Detonation: On Dec 16, a Jaish-e-Mohammad (JeM) militant was killed in an explosion which took place while explosives were being assembled in a hideout at Tral area of south Kashmir's Pulwama district.
On December 17, CPI-Maoists attacked a road construction camp and set ablaze at least 10 vehicles at Andrahal village under Bondaghati area in Malkangiri district.
Weapons seizure: On 18 Dec, security forces raided a militant hideout at Gamir-Mughla bowl around Thanamandi (Rajouri district, Jammu and Kashmir) and seized a cache of arms and ammunition.
Weapons seizure: On 18 Dec, security forces raided a militant hideout at Chandangeer (Bandipora district, Jammu and Kashmir) and seized a cache of arms and ammunition.
Weapons seizure: On 19 Dec, security forces raided a militant hideout at Choti Bati area of Mendhar sector, Poonch district (J&K) and seized a cache of arms and ammunition.
Defusal: Police defused IEDs planted by Maoists in Karaikeli on 20 December 2017.
Strikes: Maoists observed a bandh in Jharkhand on Dec 20 to protest police action against its cadre.
Strikes: Maoists observed a bandh in Bihar on Dec 20 to protest police action against its cadre.
On December 22, unidentified militants lobbed a grenade at Viewland Bazar in Ukhrul district. The grenade failed to detonate.

Arrests: On Dec 22, ahead of Joint Resistance Leadership's (JRL) valley-wide protests against the 'growing Indian oppression', police arrested Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front (JKLF) chairman, Muhammad Yasin Malik from his residence and shifted him to central jail Srinagar.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: Weapons seizure: A joint team of army and police forces recovered a massive cache of arms and explosives in a militant hideout in Shergarhi nallah in Chassana area of Reasi district (J&K) on Dec 26.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 1 January 2018, unidentified individuals placed a powerful Improvised Explosive Device (IED) near the main entrance of Mantripukhri gate in (Imphal East, Manipur). A police patrolling party found the IED on the road side, along Imphal-Dimapur highways. Soon after, a team of Heingang police and a bomb disposal squad rushed to the spot and disposed off the bomb.
An unidentified group of people hurled a grenade at a shop in Khurai area of Imphal East district on January 3; the grenade failed to explode. No one was injured.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 5 Jan, three powerful improvised explosive devices (IEDs), suspected to have been planted by Naxals, were recovered by a joint team of the CRPF and the local police from the forests under Basaguda police station (Bijapur, Chhattisgarh).

Property destruction: A group of armed Maoists raided the Kudag mines under Samri police station in Chhattisgarh's Balrampur district and set ablaze six vehicles and blew up two weighbridge units in the early hours of Jan 6. No injuries reported.

Property destruction: A group of armed Maoists raided the Kukud mines in Jharkhand's Latehar district and set ablaze six vehicles and blew up two weighbridge units in the early hours of Jan 6. No injuries reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles; Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On Jan 13, a joint team of civil police, second Rashtriya Rifles and the Central Reserve Police Force(CRPF) discovered and defused an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) planted by suspected militants on Srinagar- Baramulla road near Shalteng on the outskirts of Srinagar city of Jammu and Kashmir.
On Jan 14, security forces detected and defused an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) in Srinagar District's Maloora area, Srinagar South tehsil (J&K).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 16 January 2018, a hand grenade was hurled in the M-sector compound in Imphal (Imphal West, Manipur) by an unidentified person. The grenade failed to explode and was recovered by the bomb disposal squad of Manipur Police and set it off safely at Lamphelpat.

ACTOR1: NSCN-K: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang
NOTES: On 16 January 2018, suspected National Socialist Council of Nagaland (Khaplang) members set fire to 9 crude oil tankers at the Assam-Arunachal Pradesh border near Jagun (Tinsukia, Assam).

Detonation: On Jan 17, a forest fire triggered landmine blasts along LoC in Rajouri-Poonch belt of Jammu and Kashmir, no injuries reported. The Indian Army is suspecting that the fire was an attempt by Pakistani troops to neutralise mines.
On Jan 18, the police defused an old Improvised Explosive Device (IED) at Ponda village in Doda tehsil, Doda district of Jammu and Kashmir.
On 19 January 2018, two crude bombs were found near the Mohabodi temple in Bodh Gaya (Gaya, Bihar) where the Dalai Lama was visiting.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On January 21, Rashtriya Rifles entered the campus of Dar-ul-Uloom Islamic seminary in Sopore town, Baramulla (J&K). They vandalized the property and harassed students.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On January 21, government forces (assumed military and police) raided houses during a search and cordon operation in Redwani village of Kulgam district (J&K), causing damage to houses and destroying private vehicles.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Assam Rifles
NOTES: On 22 January 2018, an IED was recovered and defused by the Assam Rifles in Chingnungkhong village in Imphal East district (Manipur) (coded as district hq Porompat).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Assam Rifles
NOTES: On 23 January 2018, the Assam Rifles recovered a cache of arms and ammunition near Chingnungkhong village in Imphal East district (Manipur) (coded district hq Porompat).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 24 January, CRPF personnel defused a pressure cooker IED near a railway station in Pampore (J&K).
Property destruction: Maoists destroyed vehicles and sand quarry machinery in Bhupatiraopet (assumed in Kothagudem city, Telangana) on 27 January 2018 in an action against police informers.
On 29 January, members of the Bomb Disposal Squad with the Indian Army detonated several unexploded Pakistan mortar shells found in Bhourjagir village of Akhnoor tehsil, Jammu District (J&K)

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Assam Rifles
ACTOR2: NSCN-K: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang
NOTES: On 29 January 2018, a top NSCN (K) leader was arrested by Assam Rifles troop at a hotel in Kohima (Nagaland).

SOURCE: United News of India; Kashmir Times
NOTES: Arrests: On February 2nd, Tehreek-e-Hurriyat-e-Kashmir leader Syed Ali Shah Geelani was placed under house arrest in Srinagar City, and then taken to the Humhama police station in Badgam district after stepping out.
On 3 Feb, police detected and detonated an IED suspected to be planted by GNLA militants in Negmandal (East Garo Hills, Meghalaya).
On 4 February 2018, an IED allegedly planted by rival supporters was found before it exploded at a office of Naga People's Front's candidate in Wokha (Nagaland).
On 4 Feb, police forces defused an IED in Negmandal (East Garo Hills, Meghalaya) planted by suspected GNLA militants.
On 4 Feb, Maoists destroyed road construction vehicles and machinery in Madded (Bijapur, Chhattisgarh).
Property destruction: 10 vehicles engaged in road construction work were allegedly set ablaze by Naxals assumed in Chhattisgarh's Bijapur district around February 5.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKLF: Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front; APHC: All Parties Hurriyat Conference; Tehreek-e-Hurriyat-e-Kashmir
NOTES: Arrests: Police forces on January 6, 2018, in Srinagar City arrested Mohammad Yasin Malik, chairman of the JKLF, in anticipation that the leader would organize mass protests on the death anniversaries of Guru and Butt on February 9 and 11. Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, chairman of APHC, and Syed Ali Geelani, the head of Tehreek-e Hurriyat, were placed under house arrest on the same day.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Border Security Forces (BSF) allegedly foiled an infiltration bid and seized weapons in Gurdaspur sector in Punjab on early February 6.
Non-violent activity: On February 7, 2018, Pakistani forces fired across the Line of Control into the Manjakote sector of Rajouri tehsil and district. No reported casualties.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 12 February 2018, a live grenade was found attached to the vehicle of a congress supporter in Shillong town (East Khasi Hills, Meghalaya). The device was removed and defused by the bomb squad.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKPDP: Jammu and Kashmir Peoples Democratic Party
NOTES: Arrests: Police arrested the local leader of the Peoples Democratic Party in Jammu City on Feb 18 for his alleged involment in plots to kill politicians.
On 18 Feb, police detected and detonated an IED suspected to be planted by GNLA militants in Cherangre village in Samanda area (East Garo Hills, Meghalaya).

On 19 February 2018, a truck engaged in the construction work of tunnel under North East Frontier Railway (NF Railway) was set ablaze by some unidentified militants at Marangching village in Noney district (Noney, Manipur) (verified location Nungba coded). Marangching villagers declared a ban on all National projects due to irregularities in the process of paying land compensation.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Tehreek-e-Hurriyat; APHC: All Parties Hurriyat Conference
NOTES: Arrests: Opposition leaders Geelani, head of the Tehreek-e-Hurriyat, and Mirwaiz, head of the APHC, were put under house arrest on or a couple of days before Feb 22 after their call for protests against the rape and murder of a young nomad girl in Kathua District.
On 23 Feb, police forces defused a bomb planted by an unidentified group in Agartala (West Tripura, Tripura).

SOURCE: United News of India; Kashmir Times
NOTES: Detonation: An army soldier lost his leg in a landmine blast after the mine was most likely shifted around due to heavy rains in the Khari Karmara sector of Haveli tehsil, Poonch District on March 3.
On 5 March 2018, a huge cache of weapons and ammunitions was recovered by the police in a train in Dibrugarh (Dibrugarh, Assam).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Defusal: CRPF forces defused 3 IEDs planted by suspected Maoists in the Dumri area, Giridih district, Jharkhand, on 10 March.
On 12 March 2018, the last remaining members of the GNLA surrendered to the Government in Shillong (East Khasi Hills, Meghalaya).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JRL: Joint Resistance Leadership; APHC: All Parties Hurriyat Conference; JKLF: Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front
NOTES: Arrests: Authorities placed Farooq and Malik, members of the Joint Resistance Leadership and chairmen of the APHC and JKLF (respectively), under house arrest and in preventive custody (respectively) in Srinagar City on March 12. The JKLF zonal president, Kalwal, was also arrested.
Defusal: Police overpowered and apprehended an armed man near Padgampora, Awantipora tehsil, Pulwama District on March 16 before he was able to throw a grenade.

On 20 March 2018, a hand grenade was found at a residential gate at Heirangoithong Ningthemcha Karong, Imphal West. The grenade wrapped in a polythene bag was picked up and defused by a team of Singjamei police.

Property destruction: On March 28, near Gumudumaha village (Kandhamal, Odisha), Maoists torched three tractors, an excavator and a concrete mixer machine at the camp of a firm to show their opposition against construction of roads in remote pockets.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: APHC: All Parties Hurriyat Conference; Tehreek-e-Hurriyat
SOURCE: Kashmir Times; Hindustan Times; Kashmir News Service; Kashmir Observer
NOTES: Arrests: APHC and Tehreek-e-Hurriyat leaders Geelani, Farooq, and Sehrai were put under house arrest on Apr 4 in their residences in Srinagar City. Farooq was detained when he tried to leave.

On 2 April 2018, a large haul of arms and ammunition was seized in Dorengkigre town (East Garo Hills, Meghalaya) by the police. It is believed that the weapons belong to the Garo National Liberation Army.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKLF: Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front
NOTES: Arrests: JKLF Chairman Malik was detained on Apr 2 and kept in jail through at least Apr 7.
On 4 April, 2 bombs were found and defused by police in Khongjom city, Manipur.
Non-violent activity: On 7 April, armed TMC activists prevented rival candidates from filing election nomination papers in Alipore city, West Bengal

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Assam Rifles
NOTES: Around 8 April 2018 (week of), a huge cache of weapons were recovered by the Assam Rifles in Bishnupur (Manipur).

On 11 April 2018, massive haul of ammunition was seized in the villages of Dorenkigre, Chachatgre and Nengmandalgre in East Garo Hills district (Meghalaya) (district hq Williamnagar coded) . The recovery was based on tips from five arrested Garo National Liberation Army activists (GNLA) operatives.

On 13 April 2018, the leaders and members of the Zosangbera faction of the Hmar People's Convention (Democratic) surrendered and laid down their weapons and ammunition at a function in Aizawl (Mizoram). The Government handed over rewards to the cadres as part of the earlier peace agreement.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKLF: Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front
SOURCE: United News of India; Kashmir News Service
NOTES: Arrests: Police detained JKLF Chairman Malik near the Prang area, Kangan tehsil, Ganderbal district on Apr 17. Malik was visiting the homes of local youth who had been killed in clashes with security forces recently.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 22 April 2018, a hand grenade was found in front of the residence of a scientist at Manipur Pollution Control Board (MPCB), at Haoreibi, (Thoubal, Manipur). The bomb was picked up by bomb detection and disposal squad of Manipur Police and detonated safely at Haoreibi Loukon.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Operations Group
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
SOURCE: Kashmir Monitor; United News of India; Northlines
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 22 April, police forces (CRPF & SOG) seized militant arms and munitions in the Rajwar forest/Watsar area of Handwara, Kupwara district, Kashmir. The arms were seized during a CASO.

SOURCE: Early Times (India); United News of India; Kashmir Monitor
NOTES: Looting: On 25 April, 7 unidentified militants ambushed police near Goripora in Sanat Nagar area (other sources report Hyderpora area) of Srinagar district/outskirts of Srinagar city, JK. The militants took at least 4 rifles from the officers. No exchange of fire referenced. The ambush took place a short distance from J&K police headquarters.
Property destruction: An unidentified group attacked the house of an INC candidate with bombs in Daulatabad village, West Bengal, on 28 April. No casualties reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: JKLF: Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front
NOTES: Arrests: On 28 April, JKLF chairman Mohammad Yasin Malik, who was on his way to a protest, was assaulted and arrested by the police at Khanyar area in Srinagar city, J&K.
On 1 May, an explosive device found on a bus in Guwahati city (Assam) was defused by the police.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Arrests: Police and paramilitary forces (assumed CRPF) placed top- and middle-ranking separatist leaders under the JRL banner under house arrest to prevent protests, including Geelani, Farooq, and Malik.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On May 3, government forces (assumed police) vandalized the house of a an SP fighting for human rights for the 8th time since 2008, damaging property and vehicles with rods on the outskirts of Anantnag city (J&K).
Arrests: Police arrested JKLF Chairman Malik from his home and held him at Kothi Bagh station on May 5. They also placed Farooq under house arrest; Geelani was already under house arrest.
On 7 May 2018, the police found a large quantity of explosives and bomb-making equipment buried near a house in Charaideo district (Assam) (district hq Sonari coded).
Arrests: Farooq, chairman of the APHC, was arrested on May 7 after he defied his house arrest by escaping his residence in Srinagar City and trying to march towards the chalo at the Secretariart.
On May 7, the ZUF and ZUF-K arrived at a ceasefire agreement between each other, over a year after the ZUF split into two factions.

On 7 May, police defused a bomb found at the house of a BJP worker in Chhat Singimari village (Cooch Behar, West Bengal). On the same day in the same village, a BJP worker and 3 others were injured when a bomb exploded at the BJP workers house.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On May 9, a police search operation in Narbal area in Budgam district (J&K) continued after a tourist was killed by stone pelters on May 7. The police ransacked houses, damaging property and harassing people.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On May 10, a police search operation in Narbal area in Budgam district (J&K) continued after a tourist was killed by stone pelters on May 7. The police ransacked houses, damaging property and harassing people.
Weapons seizure: Police found hundreds of bombs while searching the house of a TMC activist in Bhangar village, South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, on 11 May.
Arrests: Farooq, chairman of the APHC, was placed under house arrest on May 11 to prevent him from leading protests after Friday prayers.

Security measures: On May 16, the Government of India, based on the recommendation of CM Mehbooba Mufti, announced a unilateral ceasefire during Ramadan in J&K state. They asked security forces not to launch operations.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Security measures: Extra police and CRPF personnel were deployed across the state (and especially in Jammu and Srinagar cities) by May 16 in advance of PM Modi's visit to J&K later in the week. They set up extra checkpoints, foot patrols, barriers, etc.

Arrests: Police detained APHC Chairman Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, who was already under house arrest, on May 19 when he defied his house arrest and tried to march into town in conjunction with Indian PM Modi's visit to J&K.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Assam Rifles
NOTES: On May 22, the Assam Rifles seized a large cache of arms and ammunition that was being transported in a vehicle from Ukhrul to Imphal in Manipur state.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (India)
NOTES: Displacement: Around 100,000 people fled from the border sectors (RS Pura, Arnia, Ramgarh, Samba, and Hiranagar) of Jammu, Samba, and Kathua Districts following a few days of heavy cross-border firing. The displacement occurred mostly between May 20-23.
Weapons seizure: On May 23, the police found a large cache of arms and ammunitions stockpiled by a slain tribal militant leader in East Garo Hills district (Meghalaya).
Property destruction: On May 24, in Mulchera (Gadchiroli, Maha), Naxals set ablaze a forest depot inflicting losses worth crores.
On 27 May 2018, the chairman of the United People's Revolutionary Front (UPRF) was arrested in Manja town (Karbi Anglong, Assam).

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
NOTES: Property destruction: Residents of Sugan village, Shopian tehsil/district reported that government forces (assumed RR) vandalized dozens of houses in their village on May 28 following an IED explosion in the area earlier.

Agreement: The armies of India and Pakistan agreed on May 29 to maintain a ceasefire along the borders (WB, LoC) in Jammu and Kashmir to avoid hardships to civilians following a particularly deadly few months of cross-border violence.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On May 29, a joint operation with the CRPF and Jharkhand Police and the National Investigation Agency recovered a large cache of arms and ammunition left by Maoists in Lugu Pahar area of Bokaro district (Bokaro, Jharkhand).

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On May 29, soldiers vandalized the grave of a militant (Sameer Tiger) in Dragbam village of Pulwama district (J&K).

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
SOURCE: Asian News International; Kashmir Times; Kashmir Observer
NOTES: Detonation: JeM militants threw a grenade at a joint CRPF and police checkpoint near Banura village, Pulwama District on May 30. The grenade missed its target and exploded in a nearby orchard. No reported casualties.

Security measures: The Kashmir Valley was put on high alert on June 1 following intelligence inputs that up to 20 JeM well-trained and well-armed militants had infiltrated the border and were intending to carry out attacks over the next couple of days.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) National Security Guard
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On June 1, the National Investigation Agency seized a large amount of gelatin explosive from Lugu Pahar area of Bokaro district (Bokaro, Jhakhand) after the disclosure of an arrested Maoist and Zonal member. That was the second weapons seizure in one week.

Arrests: JKLF chairman Malik was detained and Hurriyat Chairman Farooq was put under house arrest on June 2 as a pre-emptive measure against protests following the death of a young man who had been run over by a CRPF vehicle the day before.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 4 June, BDS forces defused a roadside IED in the Nathipur-Wadoora area of Sopore tehsil area (Baramulla, J&K). JeM claimed the IED and reported that it had damaged a vehicle and injured several security forces.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Pakistan (2013-2018) Pakistan Rangers
ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force
NOTES: Agreement: Pak Rangers and Indian BSF forces held a meeting in the Suchetgarh area of RS Pura tehsil, Jammu District on June 4 near the WB and agreed to refrain from cross-border firing unless provoked.

On 7 June 2018, in a joint operation by the district armed police and CoBRA destroyed a Maoist bunker and seized a large quantity of explosives, arms and ammunition detonators, cooker bomb, gelatin sticks, chemical for making explosives and a plastic drum at Jharha village (Giridih, Jharkhand).

ACTOR1: PLFI: People's Liberation Front of India
NOTES: Property destruction: Suspected PLFI activists set fire to vehicles in Dalki village, Goilkera, Pashchimi Singhbhum, Jharkhand, on 10 June, during an anti-naxal operation across Kolhan.
Detonation: On June 10, in Madurai (Madurai, TN), two people were making country bombs in a house at Valaithoppu when the bombs detonated, severely inuring the two people.
Looting: On 11 Jun, HM militants looted an INSAS rifle and ammunition from the Shadara village police post in Thanamandi tehsil (Rajouri, J&K). No violence was reported.
Property destruction: On 12 Jun, unidentified militants set two shops on fire and ransacked the house of an alleged military informer at Mulu village in Shopian district (J&K).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 12 Jun, the Bomb Disposal Squad defused an IED on the link road at Kanjinag (Kanznag) in Awantipora tehsil (Pulwama, J&K)

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force
NOTES: On 13 Jun, a BSF bomb disposal team defused two unexploded mortar shells found in agricultural fields at Maharajpur village in Hiranagar tehsil (Kathua, J&K).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) National Security Guard
NOTES: Around 14 Jun, NSG commandos were moved to a BSF camp in Humhama (Srinagar, J&K), in preparation for anti-militancy operations in J&K.
On 17 June 2018, the Government of India ended the ceasefire in Jammu and Kashmir from Delhi - New Delhi (Delhi) that began at the beginning of Ramzan. The security forces will resume operations.
On 24 June 2018, Naxals destroyed train tracks in Dantewada district (Chhattisgarh) resulting in the derailing of a goods train. No injuries were reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Galo Tribal Group (India)
NOTES: On 30 June 2018, a peace agreement called the Likabali Declaration was made in Likabali (Dhemaji, Assam) between the Galos of Lower Siang district and the Misings residing along the Assam-Arunachal Pradesh interstate boundary .
Weapons seizure: On 1 Jul, police seized a large cache of weapons and arrested a HM militant and an over ground worker (OGW) during a raid in Kishtwar (J&K).

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of India (2014-) District Reserve Group
NOTES: Arrests: On July 6, 27 Naxals were arrested in separate places in Chhattisgarh's Bastar and Sukma district (coded at Raipur capital city, Raipur, Chhattisgarh). 7 were arrested from two places in Sukma district and 20 from Bastar district.
Weapons seizure: On 6 Jul, the Indian military uncovered a large cache of weapons and Pakistani currency in a forested area in Mendhar sector (Pulwama, J&K), near the LoC.
Arrests: On July 7, Nirmal Roy of Greater Coochbehar Liberation Organisation (GCLO) was arrested in Naxalbari in Darjeeling district (WB) after he threatened a number of bombings.

Non-violent activity: On 7 Jul, unidentified gunmen held-up the car of prominent local lawyer Syed Babar Qadri in Hawal, Srinagar city (J&K) in an apparent assassination attempt. Upon finding that Qadri wasn't in the car, the gunmen backed down.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On July 11, failing to catch rioters in Soura area of Srinagar city (J&K), police and CRPF set the handcarts of five street vendors on fire, destroying all their merchandise.
Weapons seizure: On July 12, police found 20 bombs in Bibhum district (WB).
On July 12, eleven bombs have been recovered from an abandoned factory at Panihati in North 24 Parganas (WB). The bombs were defused.
Weapons Seizure: On July 13, police recovered a cache of arms belonging to banned Garo National Liberation Army (GNLA) in East Garo Hills district (Meghalaya).
Property destruction: On 13 Jul, government forces vandalised homes in Batergam village (Kupwara, J&K), during a JRL-led shutdown to commemorate Martyrs Day.

In Jul, Chinese military forces crossed the LAC and occupied territory by installing five tents in the Cherdong-Nerlong Nallan area of Demchok sector (Leh, J&K). Three tents were subsequently removed, but Chinese forces continue to occupy the area.
On 17 July 2018, Kamson and Kamei factions of the ZUF that had parted, reconciled and became one entity in the Zeliangrong areas of Manipur state (coded as Imphal in Imphal West district).
Detonation: On 18 Jul, militants threw a grenade at a police post in Watergam (Baramulla, J&K). The grenade missed the target and no injuries were recorded.

Weapons seizure: On July 23 (presumed), the police arrested men and seized explosive materials including 3000 pieces of detonators and 10000 pieces of gelatine in Malpahari (Pakur district, Jharkhand).

Agreement: On 24 Jul, an unidentified militant surrendered in the Kashmir Valley under the terms of a surrender deal offered by J&K police since 2017. The details of the militant's surrender was suppressed.

ACTOR2: ULFA-I: United Liberation Front of Asom-Independent
NOTES: On July 25, the army's Laipuli Brigade destroyed an ULFA (Independent) hideout and recovered a massive cache of arms and ammunition from the Lakhipathar area, Tinsukia district, Assam.
On 25 Jul, Umar Khalifa, commander of Harkat-Ul-Mujahideen in Kashmir, declared his defection from HuM to Islamic State through Telegram.
Property destruction: On July 25, near Kamaloor village in Dantewada Tehsil (Dantewada, Chhattisgarh), Maoists destroyed 100 meters of railroad tracks.
On July 25, a bomb squad defused three crude bombs planted underneath the rail at Gitaldaha railway station (Cooch Behar district, West Bengal).
On 26 Jul, militants, allegedly linked to HM, seized four rifles from the guard post at a former Congress leader's residence in the Bona Bazar area of Shopian district town (J&K).
On 27 Jul, an unidentified man snatched a 12-bore gun from a guard at a bank in Shopian district town (J&K).

Detonation: On July 29, in Chennai city (Chennai, Chennai), an Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK) functionary tried to throw a petrol bomb at AIADMK's house after being fired from the AMMK party. The bomb exploded in the assailant's car and injured four people.

Movement of forces: On July 30, more than 22,000 additional paramilitary personnel were deployed across Assam state, with security being put on high alert, due to the release of the National Register of Citizens (NRC) draft.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad

NOTES: On 31 July 2018, an IED planted at a shop situated opposite to United Bank of India, ward number 8, Moreh town (Tengnoupal, Manipur) was recovered and detonated safely by a team of bomb detection and disposal squad of Manipur police. Personnel of Moreh police station and personnel of 11 Assam Rifles rushed to the spot and cordoned off the place.
Weapons seizure: On August 1, in Rameswaram town (Ramanathapuram, TN), police seized 5000 explosives and arrested seven people.
Looting: On 1 Aug, alleged militants robbed a bank in Qaimoh (Kulgam, J&K) at gunpoint, stealing Rs 5.78 lakh.
Looting: On 3 Aug, militants robbed a bank in Kapren village (Shopian, J&K) at gunpoint, also seizing a .12 bore gun from the bank guard.

On 8 Aug, CPI (Maoists) destroyed train tracks near Kamaloor rail station (Dantewada district, Chhattisgarh) causing the derailment of a train. No casualties were reported.
On 9 August 2018, Maoists torched a JCB machine, engaged in pipeline laying works, in Kuwakonda area (Dantewada, Chhattisgarh).

Non-violent activity: On 10 Aug, reports suggests that around a dozen SPOs announced their resignations in the Tral area (Pulwama, J&K) following threats from militants.

Arrests: On 11 August, the zonal commandar (Ajazy Rajbhar) for Tritiya Sammelan Prastuti Committee was arrested in his (unidentified) village in Palamu district (Jharkhand). He was being held for questioning in Dehri-on-sone.

Weapons Seizure: On August 11, in Pune city (Pune, Maha), Maharashtra Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) seized bombs, bomb-making equipment and weapons in connection with an earlier raid on August 10 in Palghar.

Weapons seizure: On August 10 and 11, police seized 20 bombs and associated fabrication materials and a collection of arms including pistols and munitions from separate locations in and around Nala sopara town (Vasai, Palghar, Maharashtra). The material belonged to three Gau Rakshaks arrested on Aug 10.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 14 August, Police and BSF forces raided the home of an unidentified man in Shubhapur village near Sonamura town (Sepahijala, Tripura) and seized at least 10 bombs. It is unclear who the man was affiliated with.
Weapons seizure: On 16 Aug, the Indian military uncovered a larger cache of arms and ammunition near the LoC in the Jhangar area (Rajouri, J&K).

Weapons seizure: On August 19, explosives were seized during a police raid at Saharpur village in Pakur district, Jharkhand. Altogether 10,000 pieces of detonators, 5,000 power gel and 65 sacks of ammonium nitrate were seized.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: On 20 Aug, the Rashtriya Rifles and the Bomb Disposal Squad exploded 10 shells in the Tosha Maidan area (Budgam, J&K) during a drive to clear the area of unexploded ordinances. The defusals follow the earlier death of a youth from an exploding shell in the area.
Non-violent activity: On 21 Aug, Pakistani forces fired across the LoC in Kamalkot sector in Uri tehsil (Baramulla, J&K). No retaliation was reported.
On August 21, the West Jaintia Hills police arrested the chairman and the information secretary of the Manipur-based insurgent group Zeliangrong United Front (ZUF), in Meghalaya.
Arrests: On August 23, a senior CPI-Maoist leader, who carried a reward of INR 4.7 million on his head, surrendered to the police in Durg District, Chhattisgarh.
On August 24, the National Investigation Agency (NIA) arrested the chairman of the Kuki Revolutionary Army (KRA) in Manipur state.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On August 26, the Police and Border Security Force (BSF) recovered arms and ammunition during a search operation on the road between Nongpok Sekmai and Heirok villages, Thoubal district, Manipur. The stockpile included five live lathode shells, 28 live rounds of 7.62 mm caliber, five live rounds of .38 mm caliber, and one live round of 5.56 mm caliber, one USA made pistol, five pieces of safety fuse and 35 detonators.

ACTOR2: NSCN-KN: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khitovi Neopak
NOTES: Arrests: On August 27, a militant suspected to be a deputy secretary from the National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khitovi Neopak (NSCN-KN) was arrested in Dimapur district, Nagaland.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of India (2014-)
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On August 27, government armed forces (assumed army and police) raided the house of a youth accused of joining militancy in Qaimoh town of Kulgam district (J&K). They vandalized property and verbally insulted his parents.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Operations Group
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of India (2014-)
SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On August 28, the parents of a youth who joined militancy complained that a group of army and SOG raided their house, damaging property and verbally abusing them in S-K Colony of Anantnag town (J&K).

Property destruction: On 29 Aug, the Indian military set the family home of a militant on fire in Sedau village (Shopian, J&K). Civilians were removed from the house before the fires were set. No injuries were recorded.

Property destruction: On 29 Aug, the Indian military set the family home of an LeT militant on fire in Nazneen Pora (Shopian, J&K). Civilians were removed from the house before the fires were set. No injuries were recorded.
On 29 Aug, the Indian military set the family home of an LeT militant on fire in Amshipora (Shopian, J&K). Civilians were removed from the house before the fires were set. No injuries were recorded.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: AIJASS: All India Jat Aarakshan Sangharsh Samiti

NOTES: Defusal: On 6 September 2018, the Jharkhand Police in a joint operation with the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) recovered 33 Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs), suspected to be of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), near Bantharo drainage, at Parasnath Hill (Giridih, Jharkhand). Arrests: On September 8, in Thanjavur town (Thanjavur, TN), police arrested 350 farmers who were on their way to a protest rally against temporary restoration work.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Task Force
ACTOR2: KCP-MCP: Kangleipak Communist Party-Military Council Progressive
NOTES: On September 8, the chairperson of the banned Manipur-based outfit Kangleipak Communist Party - Military Council (Progressive) (Amon Nelson Singh) was arrested in Kolkata city (Kolkata district, West Bengal).

NOTES: Defusal: On 11 Sep, unidentified militants directed two UBGL grenades at a Rashtriya Rifles camp in Sopore town (Baramulla, J&K). The grenades missed their target and no injuries were reported in the attack.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles

NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 11 Sep, a large cache of weapons was seized in the Manuwala forests near Dhar Sakri village, Budhal block in Rajouri district (J&K) during a joint operation by the Rashtriya Rifle and SOG.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force; Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On September 11, the Assam police, the BSF and the CRPF jointly launched an operation and recovered a cache of explosives from a house at Sudarshan Pur Part-1 village (Hailakandi district, Assam). Arrests: On 13 September, Police arrested Qamar-uz-Zaman of Hizbul Mujahideen in Kanpur district (Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh), who was planning an attack for the Ganesh Chaturthi festival.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: TMC: Trinamool Congress Party
NOTES: Detonation: On September 14, two persons were injured when a crude bomb they were making went off in Cooch Behar city (Cooch Behar district, West Bengal). The incident came a day before the local gram panchayat board was to be formed. One of the injured claimed he was a Trinamul worker, but the party denied the allegation.

Arrests: On 16 September, police raided a village and arrested 3 leaders of BKU (Ekta Ugrahan), including the district president, at Bazidpur Bhoma village (Abohar, Fazilka, Punjab). The activists were planning a protest against a Congress leader over the limited distribution of water through subcanals, which has adversely affected farmers.
Property destruction: On 16 Sep, a panchayat ghar at Seer village in the Tral area (Pulwama, J&K) was partially damaged when unknown persons set it on fire.

Security measures: On 17 Sep, the Union Home Minister Rajnath Singh launched two smart fencing pilot projects, being implemented along the border in Samba sector (J&K). The projects employ the Comprehensive Integrated Border Management System (CIBMS), involving the integrated use of surveillance equipment, including night vision cameras.
Property destruction: On 17 Sep, a panchayat ghar in Nazeenpora village (Shopian, J&K) was partially damaged when unknown persons set it on fire.
Property destruction: On 18 Sep, a panchayat ghar in Drabgam village (Shopian, J&K) was partially damaged when unknown persons set it on fire.
Property destruction: On 18 Sep, a panchayat ghar at Nagbal village in the Tral area (Pulwama, J&K) was partially damaged when unknown persons set it on fire.
Between 16-22 Sep, military forces damaged property in Redwani Bala (Kulgam, J&K) after establishing a camp in the village.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On September 20, a Panchayat Ghar was set on fire by unidentified person in Kultrech village in the Chadoora area of Budgam district (J&K).

Non-violent activity: On 21 Sep, reports suggest that between seven and 47 SPOs and police constables have resigned across Kashmir following the killing of three SPOs in Shopian district and the release of an HM video message directly threatening SPOs. Government officials have denied claims of mass resignations.
Displacement: On 23 September, police forcibly evacuated around 800 Gujjar and villagers from Makkoran Pattan (Gurdaspur district, Punjab) due to flooding at the junction of the Ravi and Ujh rivers.
Property destruction: On 24 Sep, a panchayat ghar at Mantrigam village (Bandipora, J&K) was partially damaged when unknown persons set it on fire.

NOTES: Arrests: On 30 September, some 300 members of the All India Jat Sangharsh Samiti were arrested as a preventative measure by police in Gohana town (Sonipat, Haryana), after a call to prevent entry to Sonipat for Capt Abhimanyu.

Property destruction: On 1 October 2018, near Rameswaram (Ramanathapuram, TN), Sri Lankan army broke nets of at least 10 boats and chased away a group of around 1,000 Tamil Nadu fishermen over allegations of entering in Sri Lankan waters.
Weapons seizure: On 2 Oct, Indian military forces uncovered a large weapons cache in the Kuddhar area of Kastigarh (Doda, J&K).

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Defusal: On October 4, near Cherla tehsil (Bhadradri Kothagudem, Telangana), CRPF security forces dismantled two IEDs planted by Maoist forces.
Weapons seizure: On October 4, in Tadmetla village in Konta tehsil (Sukma, Chhattisgarh), police security forces arrested Maoists and recovered miniature IEDs weighing 250-500 grams each.
Property destruction: On 7 Oct, the panchayat ghar at Pinglena village (Pulwama, J&K) was damaged when unknown persons set it on fire.

Weapons seizure: On 9 October, police seized 84 semi-automatic weapons and associated ammunition from an illegal arms manufacturing group in simultaneous raids in Meerut district (Uttar Pradesh) and in Delhi area (Delhi), and arrested at least 5 people working there.

Weapons seizure: On 9 October, police seized 84 semi-automatic weapons and associated ammunition from an illegal arms manufacturing group in simultaneous raids in Meerut district (Uttar Pradesh) and in Delhi area (Delhi), and arrested at least 5 people working there.

Defusal: On October 17, in Upleta town (Rajkot, Gujarat), police defused a bomb that was sent by unidentified persons to a school administrator.

The arrests come in the light of ongoing demonstrations against a Supreme Court verdict allowing women of all ages to enter the temple.
Non-violent activity: On 23 Oct, unidentified gunmen vandalised the house of three brothers working as policemen. The gunmen left when they were unable to locate the men.

Arrests: Assumed between October 14 and October 24, in Alappuzha, Ernakulam, Pathanamthitta and Thrissur districts of Kerala state, police arrested hundreds of people including Hindu activists in connection with the violence that happened at Nilakkal, Pamba and Sannidanam during the five-day opening of the monthly Poojas at Lord Ayyappa temple in Sabarimala.

NOTES: Property destruction: On 26 Oct, state forces (assumed police and military) damaged houses and vehicles at Cheeri Koot village (Kupwara, J&K) during a CASO.

Agreement: On November 6, across Narayanpur district (Chhattisgarh), 62 Maoist Naxals surrendered to police.

It announced the construction of the Ram temple and destruction of Gyanvapi mosque (in the same location).

Detonation: On 20 Nov, an Indian soldier was injured when he accidentally stepped on a landmine near the LoC in the Balakote sector area (Poonch, J&K).

Arrests: On 26 Dec, the National Investigation Agency and police staged raids in 17 locations in Uttar Pradesh (11 locations) and Delhi (3 locations), arresting 10 suspects and detaining another 16 for questioning. The NIA claims to have busted a terrorist organisation inspired by IS, 'Harkat-Ul-Harb-e-Islam', and planning to conduct suicide attacks throughout the region in the coming months. In addition to the arrests, the raids also seized a rocket launcher, materials and explosives for suicide vests and remote explosives, handmade weapons, and mobile phones. There may have been an attack planned for NYE.

Property destruction: On January 29, in Visakhapatnam town (Visakhapatnam, AP), 25 Maoists set fire to a private bus after bringing down all the 30 passengers. There were no injuries.

Property destruction: On January 30, a truck was set on fire by suspected CPI-M cadres at a place between Purada and Bedgaon villages in Kurkheda Taluka area (Gadchiroli, Maharashtra), calling for the Bharat Bandh and opposing security operations aimed at arresting Maoists.
Property destruction: Assumed on January 31, in Mahadevpur town (Bhupalpally, Telangana), Maoists set on fire two JCBs and four tractors that were being used for construction.

Property destruction: On January 31, Maoists set ablaze a JCB machine that was engaged at a road construction site in Kalahandi district (Odisha), observing the last day of Martyrs' Week as Bharat bandh, and opposing security operations aimed at arresting Maoists.
Defusal: Between 1-4 Feb, in two locations in Chhattisgarh state, two IEDs belonging to the Maoist Naxals were recovered (assumed defused) by security forces.

Arrests: On 3 Feb, in Thiruvananthapuram city (Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala), police arrested an RSS leader and two others in connection with the country bomb attack at the Nedumangad police station on 3 Jan.

Property destruction: On February 3, around 15 CPI-Maoist cadres set on fire 10 vehicles at Dulmi village (Ramgarh, Jharkhand), over refusal to pay protection money. They raided a private road construction company premises and fired in the air to threaten the staff. They then poured petrol on the vehicles and set them on fire.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Intelligence Bureau
NOTES: Arrests: On February 3, a Central Bureau Investigation (CBI) team tried to arrest the top policeman in connection with a chit-fund scam in his residence in Kolkata city (Kolkata, West Bengal). However, the officials of the Central probe agency were detained by the local police. They were later released.

Property destruction: On February 4, Maoists torched six vehicles of a company engaged in the construction of a bridge in Desughati village near Jhiripani, under Tumudibandh block area (Kandhamal, Odisha).

On February 4, at least 10 Naxalites cadres of the Revolutionary Communist Centre (RCC), a splinter group of the former MCC, set on fire four Poclain machines and one jeep in Manadohar village under Naudiha Bazar Police area (Palamu, Jharkhand). Refusal to pay protection money was the reason behind the attack.

Defusal: On 6 February, a bomb was found by MGNREGA workers clearing sewage near the local government high school in Bhandal Bet village (Kapurthala, Punjab). Police instituted a security cordon and the school and surrounding area evacuated while the bomb is investigated and disposed of (the school is located near a river, so there seems to be little concern the bomb was deliberately planted).

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 8 Feb, in Chintagufa area (Sukma, Chhattisgarh), the CRPF and Commando Battalion for Resolute Action (CoBRA) seized a CPI-Maoist camp including a huge cache of explosives along with other articles. The rebels managed to flee before the camp was raided.

Agreement: On 11 Feb, in Telangana state, two CPI Maoist leaders (B Sudhakar Alias Satwaji or Oggu Buriyari or Sudhakaran or Kiran and his wife Madhavi alias Neelima or Padma) surrendered before the Telangana Police.

SOURCE: The Hindu; ProtectDefenders.eu; Front Line Defenders
NOTES: On 15 Feb, an anti-Sterlite activist went missing when he was taken away by presumed police forces during a train journey from Chennai to Madurai (Tamil Nadu), after he released a video to substantiate his claim of the police having orchestrated the Thoothukudi firing on 22 May 2018. He was produced in court on July 30 and remanded to police custody.

Movement of forces: On February 17, Indian Army troops were deployed to the south-western part of Lawngtlai district (Mizoram), following clashes between Myanmar Army and Arakan Army near the border region.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Indian Coast Guard
NOTES: Arrests: Assumed on 19 Feb, in Nagapattinam district (TN), the Indian Coast Guard apprehended five Sri Lankan boats carrying 25 fishermen for poaching in Indian Waters 90 kilometers off Nagapattinam. They were brought to the Karaikal harbour for joint investigation by relevant security agencies.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
NOTES: Defusal: On 20 Feb, in Apta in Panvel tehsil (Raigad, Maha), police defused a bomb found in a government bus with the help of the Bomb Detection and Disposal Squad (BDDS). Some detonators and electric devices, enough to make a bomb, were found packed in a box and kept in the bus.

Property destruction: On February 20, a low-intensity blast took place in the washroom of the Kanpur-Bhiwani Kalindi Express at the Barrajpur train station in Shivrajpur village (Kanpur Nagar, Uttar Pradesh). No casualty or injuries were reported. Some material purportedly belonging to Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) was recovered, but the blast seemed to be caused by crackers.

Property destruction: On February 20, a JCB tractor and a mixture machine engaged in road construction work were set on fire by Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres at Lodhi village under Chatrochati Police Station area (Bokaro, Jharkhand).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Farmers (India); AIKS: All India Kisan Sabha
NOTES: Arrests: On 20 Feb, in Kasara in Shahapur tehsil (Thane, Maha), police detained farmers ahead of a protest march organized by AIKS to protest against the severe drought situation, tribal land title transfer and employment issues. Around 30,000 farmers are expected to join the protest march.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Farmers (India); AIKS: All India Kisan Sabha
NOTES: Arrests: On 20 Feb, in Palghar area (Palghar, Maha), police detained farmers ahead of a protest march organized by AIKS to protest against the severe drought situation, tribal land title transfer and employment issues. Around 30,000 farmers are expected to join the protest march.
Defusal: On 20 Feb, an IED was found on a State Transport bus in Navi Mumbai (Thane, Maharashtra). The IED did not explode.

Arrests: On 22 Feb, around 150 JIJK leaders and members were arrested in the Kashmir Valley (J&K). It is unclear whether the arrests were linked to the Pulwama attack or the Supreme Court hearing on Article 35A.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Sashastra Seema Bal

NOTES: Defusal: On 26 Feb, a suspected Pakistani military unmanned aerial vehicle was shot down by the Indian Air Force at Mothala area (Kutch, Gujarat). The incident comes in the aftermath of the militant attack on a CRPF convoy at Pulwama in Jammu and Kashmir.

NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 04 March, an Indian Airforce aircraft shot down a Pakistani military drone near Bikaner (Rajasthan) with an air-to-air missile. The incident comes in the aftermath of the militant attack on a CRPF convoy at Pulwama in Jammu and Kashmir.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Assam Rifles
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: Movement of forces: On March 4, three Assam Rifles battalions and the army's Assam Regiment retreated from the area in southern Lawngtlai district (Mizoram), after three weeks of military exercise, following armed clashes between the Myanmar army and insurgents of the Arakan Army.
On 8 March, alleged HM militants snatched the DC's PSO service rifle and ammunition at gunpoint from his residence in the Shaheedi Mazar area of Kishtwar town (J&K).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Bomb Disposal Squad
ACTOR2: MCPM: Maoist Communist Party of Manipur
NOTES: On March 8, two persons left a carry bag containing a hand grenade at the office of Manipur People's Party (MPP) in Imphal city (Imphal West, Manipur). A bomb disposal squad safely retrieved the bomb from the office campus. The Maoist Communist Party Manipur (MCPM) later claimed responsibility.

Non-violent activity: On 08 March, an Indian military forces shot down a Pakistani military drone in Sri Ganganagar (Rajasthan) with ground fire. The incident comes in the aftermath of the militant attack on a CRPF convoy at Pulwama in Jammu and Kashmir.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 8 March, CRPF personnel detected and defused two tiffin bombs planted by Communist Party of India-Maoist cadres targeting Security Forces (SFs) combing the area under culverts of State Highway near Dangarbanka area under Bissam Cuttack Police limits (Rayagada, Odisha).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Task Force
NOTES: On March 9, Kolkata police special task force (STF) arrested two people and confiscated 1,000 kg of explosives (potassium nitrate) in Chitpur area of Kolkata city (Kolkata, West Bengal). The police suspected the explosives were going to be used to manufacture country bombs for use in the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections.

On 9 March, an Indian military forces shot down a Pakistani military drone in Sri Ganganagar (Rajasthan) with ground fire. The incident comes in the aftermath of the militant attack on a CRPF convoy at Pulwama in Jammu and Kashmir.

ACTOR1: PLFI: People's Liberation Front of India
NOTES: Assumed on 11 March, suspected cadres of the Peoples Liberation Front of India (PLFI), a Maoist frontal organisation torched a road roller engaged in construction work at Sanramloi village under Bisra tehsil (Sundargarh, Odisha).

On March 12, the flying squad and police teams of the Election Commission seized more than Rs. 15 lakh, eight rifles/guns, 15 live rounds and 20 local doas from various checkpoints in Itanagar city (Papum Pare, Arunachal Pradesh). The Lok Sabha elections will be held from April 11 to May 19.

On 13 March, a member of banned militant group, Khalistan Commando Force (KCF), was arrested from New Delhi by the police. The man was once a key associate of separatist militant leader Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, who was killed in an encounter by the security forces in 1984 during Operation Blue Star.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Task Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of India (2014-) District Reserve Group
NOTES: On 13 March, a joint team of Reserve Guard (DRG) and Chhattisgarh task force busted a Naxal hideout in the Nakti Ghati forest area in Gatapar police station area (Rajnandgaon, Chhattisgarh), seizing arms and ammunition in large quantity along with Naxal literature. No further information reported.

On 13 March, Naxals stormed the houses of villagers to intimidate them and torched four road construction vehicles in Puske village (Gadchiroli, Maharashtra). No casualties reported. Naxals demanded the immediate suspension of a road construction project between the Etapalli to Gatta road.

On March 13, over 9,000kg of explosives and 52,000 detonators were seized from a house in Shaltora city (Bankura, West Bengal), during a raid conducted by the police, days after the Lok Sabha elections were declared. The owner of the house escaped.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 15 March, Maoists attacked a government middle school at Sondaha (Gaya, Bihar). The school was being set up as a CRPF camp for the upcoming national elections. No encounter with security forces reported.

NOTES: As reported on March 16, at least three camps from the Arakan Army were destroyed by Indian Army forces in Lawngtlai (former Chhimtuipui) district (Mizoram), as part of a counter-insurgency drive against the militant group from Myanmar.

NOTES: On 17 March, District Volunteer Force (DVF) personnel detected and defused a tiffin bomb planted by Communist Party of India-Maoist cadres from a forest under Adaba Police limits (Gajapati, Odisha).

ACTOR1: ULFA-I: United Liberation Front of Asom-Independent

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 20 March, the police and CRPF arrested seven Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) couriers and seized explosive material from them at Tativarigudem of Dummugudem mandal (Khamman, Telangana).

NOTES: On 23 March, weapons and explosives were seized from a Communist Party of India-Maoist hideout in Palamu district (Jharkhand) by a joint team of the State Police and Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF). Recovered weapons include two rifles, two Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) weighing five kilograms each, four detonators, two hand grenades, 200 metres electric wire, 30 kilograms ammonium nitrate.

NOTES: On 25 March, a Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) camp was busted by a joint team of District Reserve Guard (DRG), Special Task Force (STF) and District Force personnel in the dense forest near Tuswal village under Mardapal Police Station limits (Kondagaon, Chhattisgarh). Naxals fled when the security forces entered the camp. Weapons, explosives and Maoist literature and pamphlets were recovered, no shoot out reported.

On 26 March, police forces seized an explosive-laden truck and arrested the driver suspected to have links with Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) in front of Kukdur Police Station (Kabirdham, Chhattisgarh). Vehicles were checked in view of the upcoming general elections.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 26 March, a Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) camp was busted during a special combing operation by CRPF in Kansar Reserve Forest (Deogarh district, Odisha). Weapons, explosives and Maoist literature were recovered, no shoot out reported.

On 26 March, police thwarted a major attack on Security Forces and Government vehicles by the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), with the recovery of an Improvised Explosive Device (IED), containing four kilograms of explosives, which was planted below a small road bridge in the interior areas in Gadchiroli (Maharashtra).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Intelligence Bureau
NOTES: On 28 March, a KCF member and one of the suspected masterminds of the 2006 Jalandhar blast was arrested by counter intelligence police personnel in Jalandhar city (Punjab).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
SOURCE: Times of India; Bangalore Mirror; Hindustan Times
NOTES: Between 27-28 Mar, in the state of Karnataka, Income Tax department, including the CRPF, raided residences and offices of JDS leaders in Bengaluru, Mandya, Hassan, Mysuru, Shivamogga and Mangaluru, in a move which is described by the JD(S) as, 'politically motivated,' conducted ahead of general elections.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 29 March, two Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) planted by suspected CPI-Maoist rebels were detected and destroyed by CRPF and District Force near Chhattisgarh Armed Force (CAF) Burji camp in Gangaloor police station (Bijapur, Chhattisgarh).

On 30 March, police recovered two bags containing a tiffin bomb (explosives packed in a tiffin box), a locally-made hand grenade, three 'arrow bombs' (arrows with grenades attached to the tip), three gelatin rods and an electronic detonator from 3 arrested Communist Party of India (Maoist) members in Dantewada district (Chhattisgarh).
Between 25 March and 31 March, a suspected militant cell was busted, weapons were seized and 5 persons arrested assumed in the Mohali area (Punjab state) by the police.

NOTES: On 1 April, an unmanned Aerial Vehicle and at least four F-16 Pakistani Air Force jets were detected near Khem Karan town (Tarn Taran, Punjab). The Indian Air Force sent its Sukhoi-30MKIs and Mirage 2000 fighter jets in response.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar

On 9 Apr, near Mettur (Salem, TN), police seized 12 country-made bombs, eight machetes, 1.5 lakh worth of gutka, three two-wheelers and a car from a group which was allegedly planning to carry out an attack on a civilian due to a property dispute.

On 9 April, the police recovered 50 kg of landmine under a culvert at Panigada village in Gajapati district (Odisha) two days before the first phase of polling of the Lok Sabha election 2019 in the state.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: On 10 April, the CRPF and the police recovered at least four bombs, including three fake improvised explosive devices (IED), from Chhakarbandha government middle school in Gaya district (Bihar). Two country-made bombs were also recovered from a bridge in the same area and defused by the CRPF.

On 11 April, two live bombs were recovered by police forces at a polling booth in Maoist-affected Aurangabad Lok Sabha constituency in Anarban Salaiya village under Dumaria block in Gaya district (Bihar), on the day polling started.

On 11 Apr, in Pedabayalu mandal (Visakhapatnam, AP), the district police removed three IED landmines planted by suspected Maoists targetting the armed forces in the Sikupanasa and Maddigaruvu areas of the mandal.

On April 11, a suspected IED was recovered from an oil pipeline at Lankashi tea estate village (Tinsukia, Assam), during the first day of polling for the Parliamentary elections. The IED was later defused by security personnel.
On April 11, there were reports of armed militants indulging in proxy voting at as many as six polling stations under Saikul Assembly area (Kangpokpi, Manipur), during the Parliamentary elections.

On April 11, Assam police personnel blocked the road by placing trucks leading to the polling station in Ladigarh village under Tamlu area (Longleng, Nagaland), during the Parliamentary elections, to prevent polling officials from reaching the location. Assam claims that Ladigarh fell with Sivasagar district, and not in Nagaland.

On April 15, a new insurgent group, Dimasa National Liberation Front (DNLA), announced its creation in Dima Hasao district (Assam), and called for a 36-hour bandh in Karbi Anglong and Dima Hasao districts, against the Citizenship Amendment Bill.

They also signed a new pact for suspension of operations with the National Socialist Council of Nagaland/K-Khango.

On 17 April, Maoists attacked a construction site near Hathkatwa River in Pirtard area (Giridih, Jharkhand) setting equipment on fire.
On 17 April, a BJP worker carrying a bomb in his trouser pockets died when the bomb accidentally exploded in Agajhola village of Bhanjanagar in Ganjam district (Odisha).

The vehicle was not damaged in the attack. Following the explosion, rebels stopped the polling party and asked the polling officials to come out of the vehicles before setting the vehicles on fire.
On 19 April, a police team diffused a bomb at the New Primary School at Dhirajganj under Adityapur police station area near Jamshedpur city (East Singhbhum, Jharkhand).

SOURCE: Imphal Free Press; India Blooms News Service; United News of India
NOTES: On April 22, two IEDs were found in front of Little Flower School at Airport Road in Imphal city (Imphal West, Manipur). A bomb squad team from the army was sent to defuse the IED. The Kangleipak Communist Party-Military Council (KCP-MC) later claimed responsibility for the attack.

SOURCE: Asian News International; South Asia Terrorism Portal; Sambad English (India); Orissa TV
NOTES: On 23 April, seven armed Maoists attacked the office of Banigocha Forest Range in Banigocha village (Nayagarh district, Odisha). The Maoists robbed the office and looted four guns from it threatening the foresters to kill them if they scream.

On 24 April, a group of Maoists destroyed the pipeline of Essar Company near Janbai village of Chitrakonda Tehsil (Malkangiri district, Odisha). The Maoists are reported to have destroyed the pipeline due to its proximity to the Andhra-Odisha Border (AOB).

Assumed on 25 Apr, in Kodagu district (Karnataka), two suspected Naxalites barged into houses, and collected rice and mobile phones from house owners at Yuvakapadi village. They were unarmed during the time of the incident. Investigation is still ongoing.

SOURCE: Times of India; Imphal Free Press
NOTES: On April 25, two leaders of the Kuki Student's Organisation (KSO) set on fire the St. Joseph's Higher Secondary School, in Sugnu village (Thoubal, Manipur). They were later arrested. The attack was made in retaliation against the recent suspension of six students.

As reported on April 27, a wire suspension bridge over the Kumey river was deliberately snapped by suspected BJP supporters, barring the voting officials from reaching the polling station in Gimba village under Tali assembly constituency area (Kra Daadi, Arunachal Pradesh), to conduct fresh polling, for the Parliamentary elections.

Assumed on April 27, BJP supporters damaged a hanging bridge leading to Cheki village under Nyapin assembly constituency area (Kurung Kumey, Arunachal Pradesh), barring voting officials from reaching the station to conduct fresh polling for the Parliamentary elections. The incident was recorded on video.

NOTES: Assumed on 28 Apr, in Hyderabad (Hyderabad, Telangana), police arrested a TJS leader and others from TDP, BJP, INC, and CPI ahead of a protest planned against the Telangana State Board of Intermediate Education (TSBIE) and their alleged errors in the final results of intermediate exams. Some were kept under house arrest. Arrests were also made across the districts.

On April 29, suspected TMC workers vandalized the shop of two BJP leaders and fired shots in the air in Matigara area of Siliguri city (Darjeeling, West Bengal) in the evening, after polling of the fourth phase of Parliamentary elections.

On April 29, a bundle of 37 gelatin sticks were recovered from the helipad in Koloriang city (Kurung Kumey, Arunachal Pradesh). Sources suspect the intention behind the planting of the explosive device is to target helicopters being engaged in transporting the electronic voting machines.
On 2 May, Maoists burnt down four vehicles engaged in road construction work in Barachatti area of Gaya district (Bihar).

NOTES: On 3 May, in Nadapuram in Vadakara tehsil (Kozhikode, Kerala), police recovered 13 pipe bombs and three steel bombs from an unidentified group hidden along a rural road near the Chelakkad fire station. The bombs were all newly made with highly explosive substance. The BDDS also conducted an intensive search following the incident.

On 5 May, a group of Maoist set on fire a vehicle and three machines engaged in road construction work near Golapalli village of Konta Tehsil (Sukma district, Chhattisgarh). No one is reported to be injured in the incident.
On 6 May, suspected militants threw a grenade at a polling booth in Tiken village (Pulwama, J&K). The grenade failed to explode.
On 8 May, military forces and local police seized rifles, ammunition and detonators from a suspected militant hideout at Gangangir village (Ganderbal, J&K).

On May 8, locals from the Muslim community claimed the seats of some motorbikes were cut with a blade, while parked outside a mosque in Marwaripatti, a mixed neighbourhood in Hailakandi city (Hailakandi, Assam).

On 8 May, a group of Maoist set on fire a mixer machine used in road construction work and a water tanker in Karka village under Etapalli Tehsil (Gadchiroli district, Maharashtra). No one is reported to be injured in the incident.
On 10 May, Islamic State declared the establishment of a province of India - 'Wilayah of Hind' - in Jammu & Kashmir state, following the death of an IS militant in Shopian district (J&K).
On 11 May, in Bengaluru (Bengaluru Urban, Karnataka), 8-10 unidentified armed men damaged 3 autos, 1 car, and at least 17 bikes to show supremacy among the residents in Koramangala.
On 12 May, Maoists set on fire a water tanker and two other road construction machines at a road-construction site near Mangutha village of Etapalli Tehsil (Gadchiroli district, Maharashtra).

NOTES: On 12 May, in Hyderabad (Hyderabad, Telangana), policemen made 40 arrests against DJS, BJP, BJYM, leaders and activists, including a BJP MLA, in a pre-dawn operation to prevent any tension in a disputed demolition site in Amberpet.

On May 13, 17 homes and half a dozen shops were set aflame in Bogakhali village (South 24 Parganas, West Bengal), one day after the voting for the sixth phase of the Parliamentary elections. The houses belonged to both Hindus and Muslims, and victims on both sides accused local leaders of TMC and BJP (opposing parties not coded as associate 1) of being involved in the attacks. Masked men armed with swords and guns burned six Muslim homes.

SOURCE: South Asia Terrorism Portal; United News of India
NOTES: On 14 May, Maoist rebels opened fire and set on fire two vehicles of a private road construction company after the company management refused to provide them with money near Sakhwa village of Barachatti Block (Gaya district, Bihar). No injuries or targeting of civilians was reported.
On 14 May, Maoists rebels set on fire three trucks and an excavator in Kirandul area (Dantewada district, Chhattisgarh). The Maoists also threatened drivers and helpers to stop their work.

SOURCE: Sambad English (India); Pioneer (India); South Asia Terrorism Portal

NOTES: On 17 May, about 30 armed Maoist rebels accompanied by hundreds of supporters attacked the panchayat office in Temurupalli village of Mathili Block (Malkangiri district, Odisha) in retaliation against the recent anti-Maoist operations in the district. No injuries were reported.
On 19 May, Maoist rebels set on fire two 'jungle depots' and a road roller, blocking several roads near Gurupalli of Etapalli Tehsil (Gadchiroli district, Maharashtra).

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) District Reserve Group
NOTES: On 19 May, two Maoist rebels, including one of them being a local CPI leader, were arrested by a joint team of the District Reserve Guard (DRG) and District Force near Mangnar village (Dantewada district, Chhattisgarh).

NOTES: On 20 May, two Maoist rebels, including one of them being a 'Jan militia commander', were arrested by police forces near Borpadar village of Jagdalpur Tehsil (Bastar district, Chhattisgarh).
On 21 May, police uncovered a suspected militant hideout in the Chatyari forest area of Rajouri district (J&K) and seized a large number of guns and ammunition.

There had been several reports of violence and attacks between political parties in the area since May 19, on the seventh and final phase of the Parliamentary elections.

On 23 May, in Burgampahad mandal area (Kothagudem, Telangana), a huge cache of high intensity explosive materials, including 45 boosters and eight bundles of fuse wire, were seized by the police from Maoist sympathizers. The materials were to be handed over to Maoists when the police prevented them.

SOURCE: The Hindu; New Indian Express; Times of India
NOTES: On 25 May, near Valayam in Vadakara tehsil (Kozhikode, Kerala), police seized 20-22 crude bombs and 400 grams of gun powder from an unidentified group at Cherumoth.
As reported on 27 May, state forces personnel (assumed police) damaged houses and shops in the Kralapora area (Budgam, J&K).
As reported on 27 May, state forces personnel (assumed police) damaged houses and shops in the Machowa area (Budgam, J&K).

On May 30, around 30 people from the Naga hills, armed with machetes and axes, entered Indrapur village under Merapani area (Golaghat, Assam), along the Assam-Nagaland border, damaged five bighas of crop land and claimed the land as theirs.

On 30 May, on threatening the workers engaged in the construction of the bridge near Bande village of Pakhanjur Tehsil (Kanker, Chhattisgarh) Maoist rebels set on fire two drilling machines and a soil testing vehicle.

NOTES: On 30 May, on threatening the security guards and Forest officials Maoist rebels barged into the go down in Deobandha village of Chandahandi Tehsil (Nabarangpur, Odisha) and set on fire Kendu leaves (Diospyros melanoxylon) worth around INR 20 million.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of India (2014-); BJP: Bharatiya Janata Party

The carcass of a dog, killed at the spot, was also left at the entrance of his residence. The attacker was identified as being part of a Naharlagun-based organization, the All Arunachal Abo Tani Association.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 31 May, a joint team of police and CRPF forces started an anti-Naxalite search operation at the forest areas of Kharsawan (Saraikela-Kharsawan district, Jharkhand). During the operation, two IED bombs were discovered and defused.

On 5 June, police seized explosives from a train that arrived at the Lokmanya Tilak Terminus (LTT) in Mumbai (Maharashtra). Five gelatine rods wrapped in paper with wires, batteries, and a handwritten note containing information about a planned attack were found.

On June 5, roadside fruit-sellers accused the police of burning their stalls in Jalukbari area of Guwahati city (Kamrup Metropolitan, Assam), without prior notice. They also complained that the incident happend on the occasion of the Muslim festivity of Eid.
On 6 June, a group of Maoist rebels set on fire an excavator and three tippers engaged in sand mining at Hatinghore village of Bano Tehsil (Gumla district, Jharkhand).
On 7 June, a group of unidentified armed people vandalized the office of NCP in Pune (Maharashtra). No one suffered in the incident.
On 7 June, around a dozened Maoist rebels stopped a bus near Farsegarh village of Bhairamgarh Tehsil (Bijapur district, Chhattisgarh) and set it on fire after allowing passengers to get off.

On June 7, BJP leaders and workers armed with bows, arrows and bamboo sticks arrived at Jhikadda gram panchayat in Mayureswar area (Birbhum, West Bengal), and stopped the digging of a pond, claiming corruption by Trinamul panchayat members. There was no report of assault.
On 8 June, a group of Maoist rebels set on fire vehicles engaged in road construction in Sukma (Chhattisgarh). No casualties have been reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)

NOTES: On 13 June, police arrested a People's Liberation Front of India (PLFI) area commander, who had been involved in killing and extortion cases, in Kharkha village under Gumla Police Station (Gumla District, Jharkhand).

NOTES: On 17 June, six Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres, including two or three women 'commanders', surrendered before Police in Dumka district (Jharkhand).

NOTES: On 18 June, a live mortar shell was found near the Bhugipura bypass in Moga city (Punjab). The shell was defused by the bomb disposal squad.

NOTES: On 19 June, a joint team of National Security Guard and Bishnupur women police arrested two KCP female leaders in Ningthoukhong (Bishnupur district, Manipur).

NOTES: On 28 June, troops of Assam Rifles conducted an operation in Suruhuto village (Zunheboto district, Nagaland) and arrested an NSCN-K leader involved in anti-national activities including tax collection and sheltering cadres.

On 30 June, Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres set on fire two vehicles and a machine at a road construction site near Lendra village under Errabore Police Station limits (Sukma District, Chhattisgarh). Maoists forced construction workers to leave the site and no one was injured.

They recovered 112 pieces of live bombs, six country-made weapons and arrested 399 people. Raids were reported from Nanoor, Labpur, Panrui, Sadaipur, Kankartala, Rampurhat, Dubrajpur and Nalhati.

NOTES: On 21 July, the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) detected and defused three IED bombs in Errabore area (Sukma district, Chhattisgarh), which had been placed at a local market. The bombs were likely planted to target security personnel.

On 28 July, police forces of India arrested a Maoist leader in Galsi village (Purba Bardhaman district, West Bengal) who was involved in killing of 5 policemen in Kukru Haat Bazar earlier.

NOTES: On 30 July, suspected militants threw a grenade at a CRPF party near the Shariefabad area of Tral town (Pulwama, J&K). The grenade missed, with no injuries were reported.

NOTES: On 31 July, police forces of India arrested an active leader of RPF/PLA in Langjing Achouba village of Patsoi (Imphal West district, Manipur).

On 1 August, district police seized 628 detonators, 70 kg aluminum nitrate, electric wires and other items near Chadhayapalli in Buguda area (Ganjam, Odisha), acting on a tip-off. Four people suspected of illegal trade of explosives were arrested.
