NOTES: On 4 August, a joint team of the District police and the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) recovered a 20kg Improvised Explosive Device (IED), planted by Naxals and packed in a steel container, from the Kerlapal-Fulbagdi road (Sukma, Chhattisgarh) during a de-mining operation.

On 4 August, one person was killed in a grenade explosion in a tailor shop at Ferkiyan in the Keran area (Kupwara, J&K). A joint search team (assumed police and military) later recovered 15 grenades from a tailor shop. The owner of the shop was arrested.

Prior to 5 Aug, more than 250 special police officers (SPOs) had their weapons seized in the lead up to the government's decision to repeal Article 370 and bifurcate the state into two union territories, over fears that they may join militant groups.
On 5 August, the central government passed two bills, repealing Article 370 of the Indian constitution and bifurcating Jammu & Kashmir state into two union territories (Ladakh and J&K).
On 5 August, the Assembly of Rajasthan passed a bill against honor killing in Jaipur (Jaipur, Rajasthan) that includes punishment ranging from life imprisonment to death sentence.

SOURCE: Hindustan Times; Daily Excelsior; State Times (India)

The arrests came amid the government's decision to repeal Article 370 and bifurcate the state into two union territories.

On 8 August, the State Government of Andhra Pradesh has extended the ban on the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) and seven of its organizations for a year under the A.P. Public Security Act, 1992.

On 9 August, state forces (assumed police) allegedly pelted houses and cars in the Bemina area of Srinagar city (J&K) with stones and bricks, in retaliation for earlier demonstrations. Windows were reportedly broken but no injuries were reported.

ACTOR1: NLFT: National Liberation Front of Tripura
NOTES: On 10 August, the Government of India and the Government of Tripura signed a Memorandum of Settlement with the National Liberation Front of Twipra (rebel group in Tripura state) in New Delhi (NCT of Delhi). NLFT has agreed to abjure the path of violence, join the mainstream and abide by the Constitution of India. They also agreed to the surrender of its 88 cadres with their weapons.

On 10 August, the Punjab Shiv Sena president along with other activists were detained by police in Patiala city (Punjab). The arrest came a day ahead of the state-level function to commemorate the death anniversary of a former Army Chief General.

On 10 August, a bomb was found in school premises of Cooch Behar city (West Bengal). On receiving the news of the incident, the Kotwali police reached the spot and recovered the bomb and took it with them.

On 10 August, about 20 suspected Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres set on fire three vehicles belonging to a country liquor factory owner in Pottangi Tehsil area (Koraput District, Odisha), objecting against the sale of liquor. They entered the premises of the liquor factory and asked seven of its employees to remain indoors, while they set the vehicles ablaze and put up a banner threatening the owner of dire consequences if he continues selling liquor in the area.

NOTES: On 12 August, at least two armed police officers and a former officer, disguised as Maoist rebels, stopped a bus near Kokadi on a 6km drive between Kondagaon (Kondagaon, Chhattisgarh) and Narayanpur and asked the passengers to get off before setting the bus on fire. They looted some valuables. Three men were arrested, while police is looking for a fourth man.

SOURCE: South Asia Terrorism Portal; United News of India
NOTES: On 12 August, two cadres of the Communist party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), including a self-proclaimed zonal commander, surrendered before the Police along with weapons at the State Police headquarters in Patna (Patna District, Bihar) with one carbine machine gun, two pistols and a large number of cartridges and one country made one round pistol

On 14 August, soldiers allegedly destroyed the rice supply and other foodstuffs of a family at Heff Shirmal village (Shopian, J&K), by mixing them with fertiliser and kerosene. A member of the family had previously been beaten by soldiers demanding to know the whereabouts of his brother, an alleged militant.
On 15 August, state forces (assumed police) damaged public property in the Hazratbal area of Srinagar city (J&K), in retaliation against earlier stone-pelting.

NOTES: Around 18 August, Maoist rebels cut a road near Kondasawali village under Konta Tehsil (Sukma District, Chhattisgarh) at about 20 points and planted three Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs), with the aim to attack Security Forces (SFs). Around 250 Maoists took camp near Kondasawali village prior to August 15 where 300 people of other villages were also called and directed by Maoists to oppose the SFs.

NOTES: On 21 August, an INC leader and former finance minister was arrested by police personnel at his residence in New Delhi (NCT of Delhi). The arrest is in connection to the INC Media case.

NOTES: On 24 August, Central Reserve Police Force neutralized a 10 kg Improvised Explosive Device (IED) on Dornapal-Jagargunda road (Sukma, Chhattisgarh) upon receiving information. The bomb had reportedly been planted by Naxals to carry out an attack on the security forces deployed in the region.

On 24 August, an explosion occurred in the house of a TMC leader in Kankartala village area of Khayrasole tehsil (Birbhum district, West Bengal). It is likely that the explosion was an accident and that the TMC had stockpiled crude bombs in his home.

NOTES: On 25 August, police forces arrested a top NSCN-R leader in Naharlagun town area of Itanagar block (Papum Pare district, Arunachal Pradesh).

On 27 August, a top JMB leader was arrested by the National Investigation Agency in Agartala city (West Tripura district, Tripura).

On 29 August, a TMC top leader was arrested in his house in Renguni village of Dubrajpur tehsil (Birbhum district, West Bengal) after an explosion of stockpiled crude bombs that were kept in his home. The TMC leader was also injured in the accidental blast.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: JKNC: Jammu and Kashmir National Conference; Former Government of India (2014-)
NOTES: On 24 March 2020, JKNC leader and former chief minister of the J&K state was released by the government in Srinagar city (J&K) 232 days after he was put under house arrest after the abrogation of article 370 and bifurcation of the state into two UTs.
On March 24 2020, 111 civilians were arrested in Punjab for violating the curfew imposed to prevent the transmission of coronavirus.
On 25 Mar 2020, police arrested over 200 persons across Odisha for violating the lockdown order of the government in response to the coronavirus epidemic.

As reported on 26 Mar 2020, villagers in Ambegaon, Shirur and Mulshi talukas of Pune district, along with some in Osmanabad and parts of Konkan in Maharashtra state, blocked entry for outsiders with logs and barricades to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, significant cases of which were spread from urban areas. State health minister on Tuesday announced that action would be taken against the social boycott of these villages.

As reported on 26 Mar 2020, villagers blocked entry for outsiders with a barricade at Khajuria village on the outskirts of Berhampur town (Ganjam, Odisha), to prevent the spread of the coronavirus in their village.

As reported on 27 Mar 2020, Tharu tribals in 50 villages in Pashchim Champaran district (Bihar) blocked the exit and entry points of their villages with nets and bushes to prevent outsiders from coming in and spreading the coronavirus.

As reported on 28 Mar 2020, residents of 10 villages under Mastiput panchayat (Koraput, Odisha) erected bamboo checkposts at the entrance of their villages and established a patrolling system to prevent outsiders from coming in and spreading the coronavirus.

On 30 Mar 2020, about 300 migrant labor workers from Jharkhand and Uttar Pradesh were arrested by police in Sundargarh district (Odisha), while crossing the Odisha-Jharkhand border during the coronavirus lockdown. Police intends to send them back to their locations of work.
As reported on 30 Mar 2020, youths set up road blockades at Uphraul village (Vaishali, Bihar) to ensure no outsiders will enter their village during the coronavirus lockdown.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Border Security Force
SOURCE: Imphal Free Press; South Asia Terrorism Portal
NOTES: On Mar 31 2020, BSF personnel recovered an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) planted by militants near a BSF post in Wangjing Tekcham Leikai (Thoubal district, Manipur).

SOURCE: TNT The Northeast Today; Assam Tribune
NOTES: Around 1 April 2020 (between 29 March - 4 April), police arrested over 340 persons from across Assam for violating the lockdown order of the government in response to the coronavirus epidemic.
As reported on Apr 1 2020, police arrested 76 persons from across Nagaland for violating the lockdown order of the government in response to the coronavirus epidemic.

On 2 April 2020, police arrested four LeT militants along with three associate members and recovered a cache of arms at Chogul town (Kupwara district, J&K) including three AK-47, eight AK-47 magazines, 332 AK rounds, 12 hand grenades, three pistol, six pistol magazines, 24 pistol rounds.

SOURCE: Imphal Free Press; Sangai Express; E-Pao
NOTES: On Apr 3 2020, police arrested 523 persons from across Manipur for violating the lockdown order of the government in response to the coronavirus epidemic.

As reported on 3 Apr 2020, villagers in Muhuldih, Gaitadih and other villagers of East Singhbhum district (Jharkhand) began patrolling the entry points of their villages, armed with lathis, bows and other weapons in attempt to prevent people from entering during the coronavirus lockdown.
As reported on Apr 4 2020, police arrested 1,780 persons from across West Bengal for violating the lockdown order of the government in response to the coronavirus epidemic.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: On 4 Apr 2020, Central Reserve Police Force and local police recovered and defused four container bombs and gelatin wires planted alongside a road at Garudbad village falling under Chakai police station area (Jamui, Bihar). Police suspect the Naxal-Maoists for planting the bomb.

As reported on 5 Apr 2020, villagers in Majhiguda, Guniapada and Kendupada under Boipariguda block in Koraput district (Odisha) began patrolling the entry points of their villages and made sure that villagers practice social distancing and wash their hands during the coronavirus lockdown.

As reported on 5 Apr 2020, villagers began patrolling the entry points to their village in Beherapati of Narla block (Kalahandi, Odisha) and made sure that villagers practice social distancing and wash their hands during the coronavirus lockdown.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: Around 5 April 2020 (between 4 March - 6 March), Central Reserve Police Force and local police launched a search operation for wanted left wing cadres and defused four IED bombs near timber machine area in Bhatuakurha and Garurbad forest areas of Giridih district (Jharkhand). Police also recovered 97 sticks of gelatin, 8 detonators and two batteries of 12 volts.

SOURCE: E-Pao; South Asia Terrorism Portal; Sangai Express
NOTES: On Apr 7 2020, unidentified assailants set ablaze a security truck carrying essential commodities for security personnel at an isolated location between Shangching Alungtang and Gamnoum Shingcha village under Shangshak police station (Kamjong district, Manipur).

On 7 Apr 2020, Maoists set ablaze a couple of tractors, mixer machines and some equipment at an under-construction bridge between Lingapalli and Kistapur near Dechlipetha village in Aheri Taluka (Gadchiroli, Maharashtra) and left a pamphlet and banner near the spot, warning the contractor against continuing the work.

As reported on 14 Apr 2020, villagers formed squads under the banner Gram Suraksha Dal to patrol villages in Nandurbar district (Maharashtra) and prevent the entry of outsiders amidst the coronavirus lockdown.

On 14 Apr 2020, residents set up barricades on four roads in Kirti Nagar locality of Nagpur city (Nagpur, Maharashtra) to prevent exit and entry as the coronavirus lockdown was extended until 3 May, despite police objections, which led to freeing of one of the barricades.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Task Force
NOTES: On 15 Apr 2020, the Jharkhand Jaguar, a special task force set up to tackle Maoists, and police unearthed six cane bombs wired over 100 metres area, allegedly planted by the CPI (Maoist) in the forests between Patahatu and Mylipi villages under Sonua police station (West Singhbhum, Jharkhand).

On 15 Apr 2020, police arrested 26 people, including 24 migrant laborers and a pickup van driver, in Mumbai city (Mumbai City, Maharashtra) for trying to travel back to Uttar Pradesh during the coronavirus lockdown.

On 18 Apr 2020, suspected Maoist cadres set ablaze four heavy vehicles, including a JCB loader engaged for construction of roads under the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) in a culvert in Rajnandgaon district (Chhattisgarh) and left leaflets, reading that the works were not being done as per the wishes of the local people.

On 19 April 2020, police defused IEDs planted by suspected Maoists in a narrow subterranean tunnel along the Dantewada-Katekalyan tar road (Dantewada, Chhattisgarh), following the inputs by local villagers.

On 20 April 2020, unidentified persons set ablaze an empty hut belonging to the Chakma community near Kawnpui village under Kanchanpur (North Tripura district, Tripura). Following the incident rumours were circulated that a communal clash took place between the Mizos and the Chakmas living the area. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: NSCN-K-YA: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang-Yung Aung
SOURCE: Arunachal Times; East Mojo; South Asia Terrorism Portal
NOTES: On 21 April 2020, Assam Rifles (AR) recovered huge cache of arms and ammunition including 170 rounds of AK-47 rifles and two magazines belonging to National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang (NSCN-K) Yung Aung faction during a search operation near Khonsa village (Tirap district, Arunachal Pradesh).

On 21 April 2020, 30 people, mostly Muslims, were arrested in Allahabad (UP) for hiding and not declaring their participation in the Tablighi Jamaat procession (which led to the spread of coronavirus) held at Nizamuddin Markaz, Delhi.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of India (2014-)
ACTOR2: ULFA-I: United Liberation Front of Asom-Independent
SOURCE: TNT The Northeast Today; Northeast Now
NOTES: On 22 April 2020, Assam Police along with the Indian Army in a joint operation arrested five ULFA (I) militants and recovered a huge cache of arms and ammunition including three MQ 81 assault rifles along with eight magazines and 323 rounds of ammunition, a Russian-made 7.65 mm pistol with one magazine and two bullets, a .22 mm pistol with one magazine and two bullets, two kg of a gelatine-like explosives material, seven pieces of cortex wire and 16 pieces of detonators from their possession in Tarai village under Sapekhati police station limits (Charaideo district, Assam).

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force; Police Forces of India (2014-) Special Operations Group
NOTES: On 22 April 2020, three militants engaged in a grenade attack on Indian security forces at Keegam village (Shopian district, J&K) however the grenade did not explode. They also tried to snatch a rifle from an Indian policemen and were chased and two of them were later arrested by the police.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: On 24 April 2020, RR along with police recovered a cache of weapons at Gundna town (Doda district, J&K) that included two AK rifles, a pistol, two AK Magazines, 580 AK rounds and 3 grenades.
On 24 April 2020, police seized a drone monitoring a patrolling party at Rajouri city (J&K) and later arrested two persons operating the drone.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
NOTES: On 25 April 2020, RR recovered a cache of improvised explosive devices at Awantipora town (Pulwama district, J&K).

SOURCE: Asian News International; Times of India
NOTES: On 2 May 2020, police recovered 153 crude bombs at a local resident's house in Lalpur village of Bhagabanpur area (East Midnapore district, West Bengal). The bombs were later disposed-off by the bomb disposal squad and a person was arrested in this connection.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of India (2014-); Police Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: On 3 May 2020, around 100 people allegedly backed by officials of Assam's forest department and police, trespassed on Arunachal's territory at Dullung Ramghat village in Tarasso circle (Papum Pare district, Arunachal Pradesh) and destroyed rubber plantations belonging to the local people. The incident relates to the existing interstate boundary dispute between Assam and Arunachal Pradesh.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 3 May 2020, unidentified militants targeted security forces by lobbing a grenade at them in Srinagar city (J&K) however the grenade did not explode and no one was injured.

On 3 May 2020, police recovered huge quantity of explosives and defused three powerful Improvised Explosives Device (IED) of 12 Kg each from Koleshwari forest under Barachatti police station area (Gaya, Bihar), suspected to be planted by Naxalites.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 5 May 2020, police and a CRPF team, in a joint search operation, recovered and defused two cane bombs from a cave under Adhaura police station limits (Kaimur, Bihar), suspected to be planted by Maoists.

Around 5 May 2020 (as reported), tribal women armed with canes formed a patrol in Chenpur village (Khargone, Madhya Pradesh) to enforce the coronavirus lockdown in their village daily from 7am to 7pm.
Around 5 May 2020, military forces of India started moving in heavy equipment and weaponry to their rear base close to Ladakh UT over the disputed area claimed by China.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of India (2014-)
NOTES: On 7 May 2020, a joint team of police and army arrested seven militants of Kamatapur Liberation Organization (KLO) and recovered a huge quantity of weapons and war-like stores during an operation in Chakrashila reserve forest area in Kokrajhar (Kokrajhar district, Assam).

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-) Central Reserve Police Force
NOTES: On 7 May 2020, a joint team of the district police and the CRPF Battalion-60 unearthed and defused five IEDs allegedly planted by Maoists near Jojodagra village under Keraikela police station (West Singhbhum, Jharkhand) during a search operation.

NOTES: On 9 May 2020, personnel of the Indian Army arrested an ULFA (I) cadre and recovered five detonators and 450 gm class II explosives from his possession at a place near Tingrai under Duliajan Police Station (Dibrugarh district, Assam) during a search operation.

On 14 May 2020, members of Tritiya Prastuti Committee torched two earth movers used in road construction in Kamad village of Panki block (Palamu, Jharkhand), leaving behind a pamphlet that warned of dire consequences if construction work would resume.

On 15 May 2020, the Security Forces (SFs) recovered and defused four Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) and petrol bombs planted by the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres from a road construction site between Bodli and Malewahi villages under Barsur Police Station limits (Dantewada, Chhattisgarh).

NOTES: On 19 May 2020, over 15 residents of Bendpur village began guarding the Ghagra and Bendpur check posts in Chakulia area (East Singhbhum, Jharkhand) together with police to ensure nobody crossed the border with Bengal during the coronavirus pandemic.

On 19 May 2020, Maoist cadres set four vehicles, including three ferrying sand, on fire near Kulbhatti and Gajamendhi villages in Dhanora tehsil (Gadchiroli, Maharashtra), as a sign of protest against the death of their senior cadre during an encounter with security forces.

On 20 May 2020, Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M Maoist) cadres set ablaze four trucks in Gadchiroli District (Maharashtra) and called for a bandh in the District against the recent killing of senior Maoist leader in an exchange of fire with Gadchiroli Police near Jaravandi village on May 2.

On 21 May 2020, Indian Army recovered a cache of small arms including two pistols, two country made guns, three magazines and 12 rounds of ammunition from an unspecified location in Udalguri District of Assam.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of India (2014-) Rashtriya Rifles
NOTES: On 22 May 2020, RR fired at and destroyed a drone camera in Kakpora town (Pulwama district, J&K) flying over the RR camp.

On 23 May 2020, police recovered a large cache of arms and ammunition including one AK 56 rifle, 16 live cartridges, 8 empty cartridges, one magazine, one handmade pistol, 32 live ammunition of .32 pistol, 6 ammunition of 9 mm pistol and a Chinese grenade from a forest at No. 1 Garoibari village (Udalguri district, Assam).

SOURCE: Arunachal Times; Echo of Arunachal; Northeast Now
NOTES: On 27 May 2020, troopers of Indian Army, in a joint operation with Arunachal Pradesh Police, recovered a huge cache of arms, ammunition and explosives including one AK-56 rifle with three magazines and 115 live rounds of ammunition, one point 22 pistol with a magazine and three live rounds of ammunition, one under barrel grenade launcher, one hand grenade, one kilogram of explosives and other war like stores from Miao Bum Reserve Forest area (Changlang district, Arunachal Pradesh).

NOTES: On 29 May 2020, the Indian Army personnel arrested a United Liberation Front of Asom-Independent (ULFA-I) militant from Tingkhong area (Dibrugarh district, Assam) and recovered arms and explosives including one 7.65mm pistol, one magazine and live round of ammunition, two Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs) and IED making materials were recovered from the arrestee. The IEDs were later defused.

On 29 May 2020, an illegal arms factory was raided in a joint operation by Kolkata Police special task force and Asansol-Durgapur police, at Niyamatapur of Kulti block (Burdwan district, West Bengal) and recovered arms and ammunition including parts of 300-350 7mm improvised pistols and semi-finished 7mm arms, heavy machines, including four lathe machines etc. Also, five persons have been arrested in this connection.

On 1 June 2020, Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres set ablaze five vehicles engaged in road construction work in Lawkhamaan Toli in Gumla district (Jharkhand) over alleged denial of levy.

NOTES: On 2 June 2020, Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres set ablaze 11 vehicles engaged in bauxite mining under Kisko Police Station limits (Lohardaga, Jharkhand).

On 4 June 2020, police recovered 24 kilograms of explosive material at Bijbehara city (Anantnag district, J&K) and arrested four persons.

The recovery included 1 desi single barrel rifle, 1 old desi pistol, 1 desi grenade, 1 detonator, 8 pieces of 7.62 mm ammunition, 17 pieces of 9mm ammunition, 1 AK-47 magazine, 1 point 303 magazine, 1 wireless set, 1 camera flash and 1 half-burnet wireless set.

The ceasefire comes as a positive development for the possible peace talks between the two sides.

Defusal: On 14 November 2021, police personnel recovered a bag containing as many as 20 bombs from the roadside near Yangbi primary school under Hiyanglam police station (Kakching district, Manipur).

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of India (2014-)

Looting: On 29 November 2021, as claimed by the victims around 60 activists and supporters of a BJP MLA attacked the house of an INC member at Heirok (Thoubal district, Manipur). They opened fire smashing window panes of the house as well as destroyed CCTV camera and monitor. In additon the attackers also robbed belongings worth over Rs. 15 lakh and a licensed gun. The INC members claimed that the attack was related to the upcoming state assembly elections 2022 in Manipur as the INC member is a rival cadidate for the BJP MLA.

On 7 March 2019, a group of an unidentified people torched a bulldozer owned by Triveni Municipality Office near Holeri area (Rolpa district). No reason for incident is reported.

On March 08, the government signed an 11-point agreement with the secessionist movement leader- C.K. Raut from the Alliance for Independent Madhesh party in Kathmandu City (Kathmandu district, Bagmati). Among other things, the agreement noted that the secessionist leader would withdraw his campaign for independent Madhesh and also accept Nepal's territorial integrity.
On March 10, a team of Nepal Army defused an improvised explosive device planted at Syuchatar locality In Kathmandu city (Kathmandu district, Bagmati).

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On 11 March 2019, suspected members of Netra Bikram Chand led party torched a temporary crusher industry along with an excavator and truck located in Krishnapur village (Kanchanpur district). A leaflet found near the incident site claimed the industry was attacked for illegally operating a crusher factory and failing to pay workers.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On 14 March 2019, Nepal Army disposed of pressure cooker bombs from two places of Gorkha bazar (Gorkha district), during the band called by Netra Bikram Chand led party.

NOTES: On April 14, police recovered arms and ammunitions, including bomb-making explosives, from the house of Netra Bikram Chand-led Communist Party's district secretary in Sainsu locality of Kedarsyun Rural Municipality near Bajhang area (Bajhang district, Seti).

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Nepal (2015-)
NOTES: On May 21, Nepal Army disposed a bomb planted in front of the gate of Chabispathibhara Rural Municipality near Bajhang area (Bajhang district, Seti). The Nepal police are further investing the incident.

NOTES: On May 26, a bomb went off when two student cadres of Netra Bikram Chand-led Communist Party (Maoist) were making Improvised Explosive Devices in Ghattekulo area of Kathmandu city (Kathmandu district, Bagmati). One person was killed and another injured during the incident. Police also recovered another pressure cooker bomb from the incident site.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On May 26, police recovered four ready-to-plant pressure cooker bombs from Koteshwor locality (Kathmandu district, Bagmati). 7 cadres of Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party were arrested in connection with the incident. The bombs were recovered on the eve of a nation wide general strike called on by the party demanding fair investigation into the death of its cadre- Tirtha Ghimire, who had died in a police firing a few days ago.

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand

NOTES: On May 26, a bomb exploded in Nagdhunga locality of Chandragiri Municipality (Kathmandu district, Bagmati), when two cadres of Netra Bikram Chand-led Communist Party of Nepal were in the process of transporting it. Both people sustained injuries as a result of the incident. The bomb was planted on the eve of a nation wide strike called on by the party demanding fair investigation into the death of its cadre, who had died in a police firing a few days ago.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On May 26, a bomb disposal unit of Nepalese Army defused an IED planted by Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party near a cinema hall in Gwarko, and a bus park in Lagankhel localities of Patan city (Lalitpur district, Bagmati). The bombs were planted on the eve of nation wide general strike called on by the party demanding fair investigation into the death of its cadre. Both the IEDs were placed in high traffic areas.

NOTES: On May 27, the Nepal Army team defused IEDs planted by Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party of Nepal near Ncell office in Srijana Chowk and Durbar Party Palace at Durbar Marga of Pokhara Metropolis (Kaski district, Gandaki). The party had called for a nation wide general strike on the very day demanding fair investigation into the death of its cadre. Both the IEDs were placed in high traffic areas.

NOTES: On May 27, the Nepal Army and police defused IEDs planted by Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party of Nepal during a nation wide general strike demanding a fair investigation into the death of its cadre.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On May 27, a team of Nepal Police defused an IED, suspected to be planted by Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party of Nepal, at the Land Reform Office in Chyamasingh locality of Bhaktapur city (Bhaktapur district, Bagmati). The party had called for a nation wide strike on the very day demanding fair investigation into the death of its cadre.

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On June 3, Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party (Maoist) seized land belonging to civilians at Chagunarayan Municipality's Duwakot locality (Bhaktapur district, Bagmati). The party hoisted their flags in the area, and also declared their land seizure through a press release. Bhaktapur Police team were mobilized the following day to investigate the incident.

On June 3, security reinforcements were sent near Chheskam village (Solukhumbu district, Sagarmatha), after reports surfaced about Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party (Maoist) planning an attack on a Police Post at the village in Mahakulung Rural Municipality.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On June 8, 18 leaders of Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party (Maoist) were arrested by the police while the former were holding a meeting at Uri locality of Annapurna Rural Municipality near Dhikure Pokhari area (Kaski district, Gandaki). The group has been outlawed by the ruling government for involving in violence and extortion activities since March 2019.

On June 10, police arrested a senior government official, who was accused of raping his daughter in Lalitpur city (Lalitpur district, Bagmati). The Police team have initiated further investigation into the incident.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On July 2, police recovered arms and ammunition in large quantities from the cadre of Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party (Maoist) in Silichong locality near Khandbari area (Sankhuwasabha district, Koshi).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former CPN(M): Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: On July 8, police discovered a huge cache of explosives in the forest of Chinggad Municipality near Birendranagar area (Surkhet district, Bheri). The explosives were possibly placed by the Maoists during the insurgency period.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On August 8, police recovered weapons and explosive materials from the cadres of the Netra Bikram Chand-led Communist Party (Maoist) in Galyang Municipality-3 near Putalibazar area (Syangja district, Gandaki). Police arrested two individuals following the incident.

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On August 17, cadres associated with Netra Bikram Chand led Communist Party (Maoist) seized land allegedly belonging to Khairabang Hindu temple in Chattreswori Rural Municipality-6 near Salyan area (Salyan district, Rapti).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former CPN(M): Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: Assumed on September 27, Nepal army recovered a large quantity of arms, ammunition and explosives belonging to the former Communist Party (Maoist) from Kureli Bhitriban locality of Pariwartan Rural Municipality near Liwang area (Rolpa district, Rapti).

On October 20, Nepal Army defused a pressure cooker bomb near the Tax Collection Post at Chalise of Dhunibesi Municipality near Naubise area (Dhading district, Bagmati). The police reported that the bomb was placed in a public area to create panic among the locals.

On October 31, police recovered arms and ammunition from the possession of six individuals, including the president of Nepal Tarun Dal - Nepalgunj in Ganapur locality near Sonapur area (Banke district, Bheri). Following the arrest of the individuals, Nepal Tarun Dal Banke held a press conference accusing the police of premeditating the arrest to deliberately target the organization and its leaders.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On November 8, police recovered a haul of explosives and weapons from Majhpali locality of Gaumul Rural Municipality near Bajura area (Bajura district, Seti). Police arrested 16 persons, suspected to be associated with Netra Bikram Chand's Maoist party, in connection with the incident.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On November 15, police recovered a huge quantity of arms and ammunition, suspected to be belonging to Chand-led Maoist party, near Gadhawa rural municipality (Dang district, Rapti). Further investigation is underway.

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On November 19, a group, possibly belonging to Chand-led Maoist party torched an excavator belonging to Emmanuel Construction in Dudhouli Municipality (Sindhuli district). The group torched the vehicle possibly because the owner did not pay up the donation amount demanded by Chand-led group. [size=no report]

On November 29, a bomb disposal team of the Nepal Army (NA) defused a powerful explosive device placed at the gate of Dhangadhimai Municipality office near Siraha area (Siraha district). Further investigation of the incident is underway.

On November 30, police recovered a bomb near an election center in Haripurwa Municipality (Sarlahi district). The bomb was placed on the election day possibly to disrupt the election by inflicting fear amongst the voters.

On November 30, police recovered a bomb in the busy Mahakali highway of Dogadakedar Rural Municipality-5 near Baitadi area (Baitadi district). The bomb was placed on the election day possibly to disrupt the election by inflicting fear amongst the voters.

On January 8, Nepal Army disposed a powerful bomb planted at a ward office of the Marin rural Municipality in Mathauli locality near Sindhulimadhi area (Sindhuli district). The bomb was reportedly placed to target the office room of the ward chair. Further investigation of the incident is underway.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On January 25, a bomb, suspected to be planted by Chand-led outfit, near Kerabari rural municipality office in Kerabari locality (Morang district) was detonated by the Nepal Army. Further information is underway.

On January 26, an unidentified group torched a repeater tower of Radio Dudhkoshi in Pattaledada locality in Solududhkunda Municipality near Namche area (Solukhumbu district). Properties were destroyed in the arson attack. Further investigation is underway.

As reported on January 26, an unidentified group set fire to a Ncell telecommunication tower located in Karmaini locality of Ramgram Municipality (Nawalparasi West district). Properties were damaged in the arson attack. Further investigation is underway. The company, which has been accused of evading taxes, has repeatedly been under attack for the past few years.

ACTOR1: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On January 27, a group, suspected of belonging to Chand-led Maoist outfit, torched a ward office of Bafikot Rural Municipality near Baflikot area (Rukum West district). Properties including official documents were damaged in the arson attack. Further investigation is underway.
On January 27, a bomb was discovered at the premises of Limchungbung rural municipality near Gaighat area (Udayapur district). Police cordoned off the area to prevent unpleasant incidents.

On 23 February 2020, an unknown group set fire to several vehicles parked at the house of a politician belonging to Nepali Congress party in Parwanipur locality of Birgunj Metropolis (Parsa district). The vehicles were completely damaged as a result of the arson.
On 11 March 2020, police recovered two bags of explosives in Rapa jungle situated at Thabang Rural Municipality's Mirul locality (Rolpa district). Nepal Army was notified to dispose the bombs.

On 15 March 2020, an unknown group torched two dozers belonging to Caravan Construction in Ratodhunga locality of Malika Rural Municipality near Beni area (Myagdi district). The fire caused damages to the properties of the construction company.

As reported on 19 March 2020, police recovered scores of arms and ammunition from Chapaha Dharapani locality of Hupsekot Rural Municipality-2 (Nawalpur district). One person was arrested in connection with the incident. Further investigation is ongoing.

On 25 March 2020, an unknown group vandalized padlocks and looted properties belonging to three government offices, including a ward office, in Bode Barsain Municipality (Saptari district). Further investigation is ongoing.
On 15 April 2020, police arrested 2038 individuals from Kathmandu area (Kathmandu district), for defying the nationwide lockdown enforced to minimize the spread of coronavirus.

Around 17 June 2020 (as reported), an unknown group vandalized Divyadeep Secondary School in Lomanthang Rural Municipality's Chhoser locality (Mustang district). Properties were reported damaged in the incident. Further investigation of the incident is ongoing.

On 22 August 2020, Nepal Army defused an explosive device planted by an unidentified group at a local's house in Shivasatakshi municipality (Jhapa district). Police are further investigating the incident.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: Around 29 August 2020 (as reported), police recovered several sets of bombs, including materials used for making explosive devices, from the cadres of Chand-led party around Tinpatan Rural Municipality (Sindhuli district).

On 24 October 2020, an unidentified group vandalized the building of Nepal Madani Mosque at Sundhara locality in Kathmandu city (Kathmandu district), allegedly to seize the land occupied by the mosque.

On 22 November 2020, Nepal Army defused two socket bombs, planted by an unidentified group, at the main gate of Agricultural Development office in Simikot rural municipality-6 (Humla district). Security has been tightened in the district following the incident.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On 23 January 2021, Nepal Army defused a pressure cooker bomb, planted by Chand-led party, at Buldol area of Araniko Highway at Banepa bazar in Banepa municipality (Kavrepalanchok district). The outfit had called for nationwide strike on the same day against the arrest of its central secretariat member.

ACTOR2: CPN(M)-NBC: Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)-Netra Bikram Chand
NOTES: On 23 January 2021, Nepal Army defused a bomb, allegedly planted by Chand-led party, at Chamtadi road along the Satbanjh-Gokuleshwor road section of Mahakali Highway in Dogadakedar municipality-6 (Baitadi district). The party had called for nationwide strike on the same day. Police are further investigating the incident.
Defusal: Around 3 June 2021 (as reported), Nepal army defused a socket bomb planted by an unidentified group at Khula manch in Khalanga town (Darchula district).

Property destruction: On 22 July 2021, an unidentified group demolished some structures at Everest Fun Park in Urlabari municipality-8 (Morang district), where the municipal meeting that was to be organized by the Oli faction of CPN(UML) was going to be held. Further investigation of the incident of vandalism is underway.

Looting: Suspected Taliban gunmen attacked a convoy of trucks carrying supplies for NATO/US forces and torched two tankers in the village of Puti while they were en route to the border town of Chaman.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Pakistan (2008-2013) Pakistan Rangers
NOTES: Arrests: Around 1 January 2010, agents of a Pakistani law enforcement agency raided an Afghan refugee camp in the Muslim Bagh area in Quetta (Balochistan) and arrested an alleged Indian intelligence agent (from the RAW agency).

ACTOR2: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
NOTES: On 24 Jan, a suspected U.S. Drone was shot down by Taliban militants near Hamzoni in the Miran Shah area (NWA, FATA).
Agreement: On 4 Feb, a peace agreement was reached at a government-sponsored jirga between two religious sects (Shia and Sunni) which had been engaged in hostilities for 14 years in Kohat (KP).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Pakistan (2008-2013) Pakistan Rangers
NOTES: Arrests: More than 50 people, including members of various political parties, were arrested by the Pakistan Rangers (in association with Karachi police forces) after they took over responsibility for security in Karachi following prolonged political violence.

SOURCE: Daily Regional Times (Pakistan); Right Vision News
NOTES: Arrests: Around 18 Feb, the Pakistan Rangers arrested 59 people, including 3 people connected to al-Qaeda and the TTP, and recovered various arms during raids in different areas of Karachi city.

Arrests: Security forces arrested more than 100 suspected militants and recovered large quantities of arms in the Khyber and Mohmand Agencies, with the majority arrested in Jamrud Tehsil. The Scouts Force and Khasadar Force took part in the operation and many of the suspects are Afghan immigrants.
Arrests: A key militant leader belonging to proscribed Lashkar-i-Taiba and his 34 Afghan pupils were arrested and his illegal FM radio was sealed in a media raid on a religious seminary.
Arrests: Over 106 militants were arrested in operations in Bajaur, Khyber and Mohmand Agencies (coded as capital of Orakzai Agency).
Arrests: Over 106 militants were arrested in operations in Bajaur, Khyber and Mohmand Agencies (Khar listed as capital of Bajaur Agency).
Agreement: On March 2, over 600 militants surrendered to the government authorities in Mohmand Agency (FATA).
Following military operations which have 'crippled' the Taliban elsewhere, the TTP leadership have moved to North Waziristan and Orakzai Agency.

ACTOR2: AQIS: Al Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent
NOTES: Arrests: On March 7, a senior al-Qaeda leader of American nationality, Adam Yahiye Gadahn, was arrested in Karachi city (Sindh) according to Pakistani and American diplomatic sources.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of India (2004-2014) Border Security Force
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On March 11, Indian BSF fired across the border with Pakistan in the Shakar Garh sector (Narowal, Punjab). Later a military official claimed the incident had not occurred.
Arrests: On March 13, police have arrested at least 40 suspects in Peshawar city (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa) in connection with the recent bombings in Lahore.
Arrests: On March 13, at least 50 people were arrested in connection with the Mar.12 blasts in Lahore city (Punjab).

Security forces moved into the Kaluba area of Orakzai Agency and set up checkposts and tightened security going into the area, allegedly in preparation for an upcoming sustained offensive. This followed an attack on militant hideouts in the area.
Agreement: Local Taliban in Kurram Agency released 22 hostages to the Kurram Agency Lashkar. In return, the national Lashkar announced a ceasefire with the Taliban in the area.
Local Taliban have claimed to have regained control of several villages including Gedara and Hashmet Khan Kali in Orakzai Agency.

Property destruction: On 31 March 2010, suspected Taliban militants burned down 5 schools in Spin Kada, Dhand Garhi, and Shalon Talab (lat/longs not available) and a basic health unit in Utmankhel area, and later blew them up.
Security forces have claimed they have gained control over several areas in Lower Orakzai, including Bagram, Sheraz Garhi, and Anari Kalay
Security forces established checkposts in Mohmand Agency for the first time since militants were pushed out of the area.
Arrests: On April 20, security forces arrested more than 200 suspects militants during search operations in Mingora area (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa).
A top commander of the Harakat ul-Mujahideen was arrested by Sindh's Crime Investigation Department (CID) after some resistance.
Property destruction: Six armed men on motorbikes intercepted 3 buses in Karachi and set them on fire in reaction to a wave of targeted killings of political workers across the city.

Property destruction: A few unidentified militants set the house of the Pakistan Muslim League-Functional (PML-F) leader on fire in Udar Shah Colony in the jurisdiction of the B-Section Police Station on 3 July 2010 in Khairpur.
Arrests: On July 11, security forces of Pakistan arrested more than 70 militants including five key TTP commanders from Nowshera (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa).
Property destruction: An unidentified group set a NATO container on fire in Pirangabad, Mastung on 31 August 2010. The container was destroyed but no loss of life reported.
Property destruction: Suspected TTP set ablaze a NATO trailer on 18 Oct 2010 in Khuzdar. No casualties reported.
Property destruction: On 19 Oct 2010, suspected TTP militants set two Nato trailers on fire in Dasht area of Qalat. No casualties occurred.
Arrests: On November 29, police arrested 52 suspected militants in Kohat (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa).
Property destruction: On 7 January 2011, suspected TTP militants torched two empty oil tankers in Landi Kotal. Additional research shows them to be NATO tankers.
Property destruction: A NATO container was set on fire by unidentified armed men in Khuzdar on 9 January 2011.
Property destruction: At least 20 NATO oil tankers were set on fire by unidentified militants in a pre-dawn attack near Dera Murad Jamali on 15 January 2011.
Property destruction: Two NATO oil tankers were destroyed when unidentified armed men opened fire on them on the Sindh-Balochistan Highway on 27 January 2011.

Arrests: On January 29, security forces arrested over a suspected TTP 100 militants from Nawagai Tehsil (Bajaur Agency, FATA), after an offensive operation which also resulted in the deaths of 15 militants. The incident took place on 29 January 2011.

Property destruction: Three NATO containers were attacked by unidentified militants in Wadh, Khuzdar, Balochistan on 30 January 2011. Two caught fire and one overturned into a ravine. Traffic in the area was disrupted as a result.
Agreement: On 24 February, at least 32 suspected TTP militants laid down arms and surrendered to security forces in Mamond (Bajaur, FATA).
Property destruction: Two NATO oil tankers were destroyed when unidentified men opened fire on them near Khuzdar on 24 February 2011.
Property destruction: Unidentified gunmen attacked two NATO trucks in Kalat (typo in article) on 26 February 2011.

Property destruction: On February 27, unidentified gunmen attacked two NATO trucks carrying supplies to Afghanistan near Mangocher in Quetta area (Balochistan). They set the trucks on fire after asking the drivers to leave.
Property destruction: Two NATO oil tankers were torched in Mach, Balochistan by unidentified armed men in the week of 9 March 2011.
Property destruction: 3 NATO oil tankers were torched by unidentified armed men in Sibi, Balochistan on 23 March 2011.
Property destruction: Unidentified attackers in Kallar Syedan, Tehsil Rawalpindi set two NATO oil tankers on fire on 6 Apr 2011. No casualties reported.
Property destruction: Two tankers carrying fuel for Nato forces stationed in Afghanistan were set on fire in Bolan district of Balochistan on 6 Apr 2011.
Property destruction: Unidentified armed men attacked a NATO tanker in Dhadar on 21 Apr 2011. No loss of life reported.

NOTES: Arrests: On April 29, following bombing of three Pakistan Navy (PN) buses within two days in the metropolis, Sindh Rangers launched a search operation in different vicinities of Baldia Town (Sindh), detaining around 100 suspects and recovering weapons.

Change to armed group: On June 28, a split in the TTP caused Kurram Agency leader Fazal Saeed Haqqani to form the TTIP. Property destruction: On July 22, the houses of 2 MQM-H activist were set ablaze by unidentified armed men in Karachi city.

Property destruction: On August 17, a NATO oil tanker was destroyed in an attack by an unidentified armed group in Quetta (Balochistan).
Property destruction: On August 19, 4 NATO oil tankers were torched by unidentified armed individuals near Quetta (Balochistan).

Property destruction: On September 27, 3 NATO oil tankers were destroyed by unidentified gunmen in Dasht (Balochistan).
Property destruction: On October 5, unidentified armed men destroyed 3 NATO oil tankers in Mach (Balochistan).
Property destruction: On October 13, 4 NATO oil tankers were destroyed in an attack by unidentified gunmen in Shikarpur (Sindh).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Pakistan (2008-2013) Pakistan Rangers
NOTES: Arrests: On October 23, Pakistani forces forced to land an Indian helicopter which had allegedly flown into its airspace in the Skardu area (Gilgit-Baltistan). The helicopters 4 passengers, including at least one member of the military, were taken into custody.

Property destruction: On November 21, three containers, carrying supplies for NATO forces stationed in Afghanistan were torched after unknown assailants opened fire at the vehicles and later set them on fire after sprinkling petrol on them.
